loans.name: Aperila

texts.en: Aperila F., 26 years old, runs a sewing business, and also looks after her grandparents. She charges less money for her seamstress services from customers that provide their own materials. Aperila's two sisters work at Yasaki, a nearby village, but they also do not make enough money to support the family. Aperila is looking for a better market to sell her services and is  planning to use the US$300 loans to purchase fabrics, threads, needles and new parts for her sewing machine, so that she can expand her business by adding new clothing designs and fabrics.

loans.use: Purchase of fabrics, threads, needles, and new parts for a sewing machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Tolusefulutasi

texts.en: Mrs. S. is talented in weaving and creating designs for fine mats. She recently added a plantation to her business activities, and now two days a week she delivers taro and bananas to a market. During the rest of the week, she works as a mat-weaver. She prefers weaving large mats, because they sell for a lot of money - she can make US$160 per week off her plantation, while each fine mat sold earns her US$400. However, S. is not able to sell a mat every single day, and therefore decided to start the plantation as an additional business. Her husband is unemployed, so S.'s work is very important for supporting the family. She is now asking for a loan of US800 to be able to purchase chemicals, a wheel barrow, a crowbar, and other supplies for her plantation and home.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals, a wheel barrow, a crowbar, and other supplies for a plantation and for home improvement

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Faleoo

texts.en: Faleoo M. is one of the new members of the Samatau Center. She is in her early thirties, and she runs two businesses: selling chips and fine mats. Faleoo works at her chip store five days a week - she sells chips at a school during recesses. She can sell sixty to ninety bags of chips a day and earn up to US$36. Faleoo weaves fine mats in the evenings and during weekends. The fine mats are in high demand for special events such as weddings and funerals. The white, soft fine mats are very expensive - 10 inches can sell for up to US$200. The price of the mats depends on their size and fineness. Faleoo’s husband has no job, and the couple has six children who are young and in school. Faleoo is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase plastic wrap, cans of oil, a new fryer and pots, so that she is able to continue her chip business and to support her children in school.

loans.use: Purchase of plastic wrap, cans of oil, a new fryer and pots

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Lagimaina

texts.en: Lagimaina S. is twenty five years old. She has two children, and her husband is a carpenter. She runs a sewing business, where she faces uncertain costs that depend on materials and urgency. She attends the flea market at Apia to buy the materials. Lagimaina is also the secretary of the Manono C center (borrowing group), and she is supporting her young children who are in kindergarten. She is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase a new sewing machine andsupplies for home improvement. This is her fifth loan and she is expecting to borrow more in the future to improve her business as well as to support her children. Lagimaina is very hard-working and will be able to repay the loan.

loans.use: Purchase of a new sewing machine and supplies for home improvement

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Leata Mauigoa

texts.en: Leata helps run her family plantation and also raises chicken to augment her income. Poultry is in high demand on special occasions such as funerals, weddings, and even birthdays. On her plantation, she grows crops such as taro and bananas. When all of the poultry cannot be sold, it can be used as food for the family. Feeding the chickens is one of Leata’s daily tasks, which take place early in the morning and again in the evening. She likes to feed the chickens “penu,” a type of feed made from coconuts instead of rice, as she believes that the chickens grow faster this way. She does not have to spend the extra money to buy rice and can simply collect the coconuts in her backyard. Her next loan of US$500 will be used to buy wires for fencing to protect the the chickens from dogs. In addition, some of the money will be used to purchase fertilizers and chemicals for her plantation.

loans.use: Purchase of fence wire for her poultry farm and chemicals, fertilizers, and knives for her plantation

loans.name: Suong

texts.en:
Mrs. Suong E., age 50, is a housewife with seven children. Several of her children work in garment factories, earning $70 per month each and others of her children are still students. Her husband works producing palm sugar and fishing, earning about $7 per day in revenue. To make palm sugar, he climbs up the palm tree to tap the sap. He then boils the sap to produce sugar and sells it in the market.

Mrs. Suong E. would like to borrow $1,200 to purchase additional tools to increase the quantity of palm sugar that her husband can produce, thereby increasing their income and financing their children’s education.

She is pictured with her husband in their home.

loans.use: To purchase tools to aid in the production of palm sugar.

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Suong Ey start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos raises and sells pork. He started with 3 baby pigs several years ago; he now owns 18 pigs.

The loan he is requesting is smaller than usual because it’s the off-season for sugarcane. When it is in season, people spend more money because the local economy is based largely on the sugarcane industry (that is where most of the jobs are), then he takes out larger loans to advance his business quicker.

With his past loans he has been able to buy the title to his house and his land, a feat that very few people in his community are ever able to do. His dream is to continue earning money, and saving so that one day soon he can buy a bigger and stronger house. He says he worries that if a strong hurricane comes it will destroy the house he and his family live in—a house made of wood and a corrugated zinc roof.

Carlos is very thankful for your help with this loan, and is excited to work hard and realize all of the blessings it will bring him.

NOTE: This $1050 loan will fund Carlos' business as well as seven other businesses in his solidarity group. They have all gone through Esperanza business training program and will receive equal shares of the loan to invest in their respective business and pay back the loan together. The entire group must pay in full and on time, otherwise group members must make up the deficit before any payment can be made. This creates accountability among the group members because each one shares in the struggles and successes of the other members in their group.

loans.use: To invest in his business

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen says her past loans have helped improve her life a lot; she saves and re-invests almost every penny she makes. She says this loan will help her to buy another pig, which she will breed so that she will have more in about 7-8 months.

Carmen hopes to expand her livestock to incluD. hens and chickens by the end of the year; she knows that a more diverse product can increase her earnings. She is very thankful for her loan, and knows that it will help her to get closer to achieving her dreams.

NOTE: This $1200 loan will fund Carmen's business as well as seven other businesses in her solidarity group. She and seven other women micro-entrepreneurs came to Esperanza and formed their group. They have all gone through Esperanza business training program and will receive equal shares of the loan to invest in their respective business and pay back the loan together. The entire group must pay in full and on time, otherwise group members must make up the deficit before any payment can be maD.. This creates accountability among the group members because each one shares in the struggles and successes of the other members in their group.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Mrs. Van V., age 37, works selling grocery products out of her home in the village to earn $2.50 per day. Her husband, age 39, works as a moto-taxi driver, earning about $1.50 each day. They have two children, one of whom is a student and another who is too young to attend school. She would like to borrow $750 to purchase a motorbike in order to transport goods and make deliveries to her customers, which will expand her business and increase revenue. She plans to use the increased income to care for her family and pay for her children’s education.

She is pictured with her children at her grocery stand.

loans.use: To puchase a motorbike to expand her grocery business.

loans.name: Petronila

texts.en:
Petronila sells small articles of clothing, accessories and sweets from a bag as she walks through the streets of the various communities in her area. She probably walks 10-15 miles a day as she sells her items.

Every night she makes homemaD. coconut-bread, a delicious sweet bread that everyone loves to buy from her. This will be the fifth loan that she has taken out, and she is very excited to continue improving her life.

She plans to use the loan to purchase a better variety of clothes to sell, and she hopes to save enough so that one day she can build a strong and safe home of concrete for her family, and so that she can also build a store where she can sell her items without having to walk so much each day.

She is very involved with her local Catholic church, and wants nothing more than to give her nine children a shot at a better life. She is very thankful for your help with this loan.

NOTE: This $1,000 loan will fund Petronila's business as well as four other businesses in her solidarity group. She and four other women micro-entrepreneurs came to Esperanza and formed their group. They have all gone through Esperanza business training program and will receive equal shares of the loan to invest in their respective business and pay back the loan together. The entire group must pay in full and on time, otherwise group members must make up the deficit before any payment can be maD.. This creates accountability among the group members because each one shares in the struggles and successes of the other members in their group.

loans.use: To purchase better variety of clothes for resale

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Mrs. Phun S., age 30, sells mushrooms at the market, earning $3 per day. Her husband, age 28, is a construction worker, earning around $3 per day. They have two children who are too young for school. In order to expand her mushroom business and increase revenue, she would like to borrow $500 to purchase seeds to plant mushrooms in addition to gathering them, thereby increasing her stock. She plans to save the extra income to finance her children’s education.

She is pictured with her husband in front of her inventory of mushrooms.

loans.use: To purchase seeds to expand her mushroom inventory.

loans.name: Yenisa

texts.en:
Yenisa lives in a Batey, the migrant camps which house immigrant Haitian sugar-cane workers and their families. She is 34 years old, single and raises her three children by herself: a boy aged 6, and two girls aged 5 and 2. She lives with her family in one of the Batey company houses, barracks owned by the nationalized sugar-cane industry.

She has been an Esperanza client for over two years. This is her fifth loan from Esperanza and she has paid back the other four successfully. She hopes to use her loan to continue selling small food items to her community, such as chicken and rice. She wants to buy more products with her loan.

She uses the profits from her store to buy medicine and to take care of her children. They go to school so she buys their uniforms.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Mrs. Long K. S., age 43, sells vegetables in the market, earning about $1.50 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning about $1.50 per day as well. They have five children: one child is a toddler, one child is a student, and three children work as goldsmiths earning $5 per day each. As her children are the primary breadwinners in the family, she would like to support the growth of their business. She requests this loan of $1,200 in order to purchase additional goldsmith tools so that her children can work for themselves and expand their business. The additional income will finance their younger siblings' education.

She is pictured with her husband and her young daughter.

loans.use: To purchase goldsmith tools.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Long Kim Srean has paid this loan back early.

Thanks to your support, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to help finance their small businesses and to support their families. We hope you will continue your support on Kiva.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia lives in Batey, the migrant camps which house immigrant Haitian sugar-cane workers and their families. She lives with her family in one of the Batey company houses, barracks owned by the nationalized sugar-cane industry. She is 29 years old, unmarried and raises her children on her own. She has two children, ages 11 and 15.

Her Colmado, a small grocery store, provides food and small convenience goods to her community (i.e. rice, cooking, oil, soap). She buys her products in El Seybo and sells them to her community.

This is her third loan from Esperanza. She successfully paid back her first two loans of 300 USD and 330 USD respectively. Her profits allow her to buy food for her family and keep sending her children to school. She moved to the Dominican Republic from Haiti 8 years ago.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Mrs. Hun N., age 49, is a market vendor selling fish to earn about $4 per day. She has four children, two of whom are students and two of whom help their mother sell fish. She would like to borrow $700 in order to finance her husband’s transportation business. $700 will buy a trailer to attach to his motorbike so that he can transport people in the surrounding area, making about $5 per day. This additional income will help give financial security to the family and finance their children’s school fees.

Her husband is standing next to the trailer she would like to purchase for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to start a transportation business.

loans.name: Senitima

texts.en: Senitima T. is a widowed lady and one of the oldest members of Samatau 4 Center. She has two children that work, and Senitima herself has joined the SPBD loan program and is the owner of a small business: she has been running a canteen for the past three years. During weekdays, Senitima sells food to school children. On hollidays and weekends, she weaves small Samoan fans. These fans can be sold for 5-10 tala (US$2-4) each, depending on the size and the materials used. If she can sell twenty fans a week, Senitima earns US$40, plus US$160 from the canteen. She will use the current loan of US$700 to purchase inventory for her canteen, so that she is able to pay for her children’s school fees and her family’s home improvement.

loans.use: Purchase of inventory to restock a canteen

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Mrs. Say L., age 35, works with her husband to sell fish in the market, making about $12 per day in combined revenue. They have five children, four of whom are students and one of whom is too young for school. She would like to borrow $800 to purchase two calves to raise so they can sell them in 6 months to generate additional income for the family to pay for the children’s education. Her husband is pictured in the photo on the motorbike transporting fish to the market.

loans.use: To purchase calves to raise and sell.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Say Lorng and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Mrs. Hem R., age 50, works with her husband to farm a plot of land growing rice crops and other vegetables. They sell their produce at the market, earning about $2 per day. They have five children, four of whom are married and living with their own families and one of whom is a student who lives at home. In order to purchase more rice seeds and fertilizer to increase the output of her farmland, she would like to borrow $800. She is pictured with her husband in their home.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds, fertilizer to expand her crops.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Hem Roeun and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Vuth

texts.en: Mrs. Vuth A., age 39, works as a farmer, selling her vegetables in her community for about $3 per day. Her husband works grinding rice crops for the villagers, earning about $3 per day as well. They have five children. Two children are employed in a garment factory making about $70 per month each, and three children are students. In order to purchase a hand-tractor to more efficiently till the soil in her field, she would like to borrow $1,100. This will allow her to increase her crop output and thus increase her income to provide an education for her children. Her husband is pictured in front of the tractor she would like to purchase for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor for farming.

loans.name: Nup

texts.en: Mrs. Nup H., age 40, raises pigs to sell and earns $2 per day. Her husband is a teacher, earning $4 per day. They have three children who are students. In order to diversify her business and increase her income, she would like to borrow $1,000 to purchase a rice mill. This will enable her to charge a fee to grind her neighbors’ rice, separating the rice from the husk, thereby increasing her income and her ability to pay for her children’s education. Her husband is pictured in the photo in front of the rice mill she would like to purchase.

loans.use: To purchase a rice mill to start a rice grinding business.

loans.name: Hang

texts.en: Mrs. Hang S., in her mid-30s, grows rice crops in her rice paddy while her husband works as a fisherman. Together they earn about $2.50 per day. They have five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory earning $70 per month each, two are students, and one is unemployed. To take full advantage of the rainy season, she would like to borrow $800 to purchase a boat with a motor and a fishing net to catch fish more efficiently during the plentiful rainy season. The extra income they can save during the monsoon season helps them survive during the dry months of the year when there is no fishing. The increased income will also help finance their children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase a boat with a motor and a fishing net.

loans.name: Heab

texts.en:
Mrs. Heab T., age 41, sells fruit in the market, earning about $4.75 per day in revenue. Her husband works as a mechanic, making about $7.30 per day in revenue. They have three children, two of whom are students and one of whom is becoming a monk.

In order to expand her husbands business to meet customer demand, Heab would like to borrow $1,000 in order to buy a stand for her husband to run his business out of. A location closer to customers will increase income for the family, providing greater financial security and financing their children’s school fees.

loans.use: To purchase a mechanic's stand.

loans.name: Jero Ketut Pudak

texts.id:
In her neighborhood of Ekasari village Jero Ketut Pudak is considered a successful farmer. Because her 1 mother pig bore 9 piglets, healthy dan fat. Besides that Jero Ketut Pudak raised 3 other piglets to be fattened. Her husband Gusti Nyoman Tulis work as a building laborer. Every day Jero Ketut Pudak with persistence raised these 9 one-month old piglets. Loan from Dinari for Rp 1,700,000 (about US$190-200, depending on exchange rate) are used to buy rice and wheat shell clippings, and konsentrat (local brand). Animal feed price has increase lately, so that the Rp1,700,000 ($200) was not sufficient, since her husband who works as laborer only earns Rp40,000 (about $5)/day. The additional capital from Dinari would be used to cover the animal food shortage. That is why Jero Ketut Pudak hopes that she could obtain additional loan from Dinari. The stall condition is very simple from wood. The plan is that after harvest she could build a permanent stall. Those are Jero Ketut Pudak wishes. She also has 2 raise 2 children still at school.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Di lingkungan tetangganya di desa Ekasari Jero Ketut Pudak termasuk peternak yang berhasil. Karena 1 induk babinya beranak 9 ekor, anaknya sehat dan gemuk. Disamping itu Jero Ketut Pudak memelihara 3 ekor penggemukan. Suaminya Gusti Nyoman Tulis bekerja sebagai tukang bangunan. Setiap hari Jero Ketut Pudak dengan tekun memelihara 9 anak babinya yang baru berumur 1 bulan. Semua modal pakan yang dipergunakan didapat dari Dinari. Modal yang dipinjam sebesar Rp.1.700.000,- modal ini dipergunakan untuk membeli dedak padi , dedak poral dan konsentrat. Setiap hari semua babinya diberi makan 2 kali setiap pagi dan sore. Harga pakan saat ini semua naik, modal Rp.1.700.000,- masih kurang oleh sebab itu suami Jero Ketut Pudak rajin bekerja sebagai tukang karena upah tukang perhari Rp.40,000,-. Modal tambahan ini bisa untuk menutupi kekurangan pakan ternaknya. Oleh sebab itu Jero Ketut Pudak sangat berharap pinjaman dari Dinari bisa meningkat. Kondisi kandang Jero Ketut Pudak masih sederhana kandang kayu. Rencananya panen nanti kandangnya akan dibuat kandang permanen itu harapan Jero Ketut Pudak disamping itu juga bisa membiayai 2 anaknya yang masih duduk dibangku sekolah.

loans.use:
To buy pig feedsock and animal feed

Membeli bibit dan pakan babi

loans.name: Vay

texts.en: Mrs. Vay S., age 26, works in a garment factory, earning around $3 per day. Her husband works as a farmer, growing crops and raising pigs. They have one child in school. In order to expand the stock of pigs that they raise and sell, she would like to borrow $300 to purchase feed for their pigs. The increased stock of pigs will raise their revenue and allow them to further invest in the growth of their business.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina M. is thirty years old, and she is on her sixth loan. She has three children: 2 are in school and 1 is in kindergarten. Her husband is a farmer who owns a very big plantation. Sina supplies the taro and bananas grown on the farm to the market on Wednesdays and Saturdays. For her Pork Buns business, Sina takes orders from shops and stores on Mulifanua Wharf. She is charging 1 tala (US$0.40) per pork bun, and she can supply sixty to eighty pork buns a week. She sells pork buns seven days a week. She is doing her best to continue her business, and she wants to make sure that she can supply the best product so she can satisfy her customers’ needs. Sina is asking for a loan of US$900 to purchase materials and supplies for her pork bun business as well as for home improvement. She hopes that in the next five years she will be able to afford building a good house for family.

loans.use: Purchase of materials and supplies for a pork bun business and for home improvement

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mr. Keo Phov, age 32, farms his land and sells the vegetables, making $2 per day in income. His wife works in a garment factory, earning about $3 per day. They have three children who are students. He would like to borrow $500 in order to build a new home to house his growing family. He is pictured in the photo standing on the land where he would like to build his home.

loans.use: To build a home for his growing family.

loans.name: Ni Wayan Astiti

texts.id:
As a good housewife, Wayan Astiti could not just sit still. Besides taking care of her 2 school age children, Wayan Astiti also runs a pig farming business. Wayan Astiti's husband Ketut Rana is also busy raising government own cows, so everybody is busy. Wayan Astiti raise 1 mother pig and 1 male pig. The mother pig is now 1 month pregnant. The male pig is quite profitable, each husbandary could earn her Rp 30,000 (about US$3.30). Each month from husbandary Wayan Astiti could earn Rp 500,000 (about $55). That is why Wayan Astiti dare to borrow from Dinari for Rp1,700,000 (about $187). This capital will be used to buy rice shell clippings, wheat shell clippings and tofu leftovers. Since tofu leftovers is good for pregnant mother pig, Wayan Astiti is persistent in learning how to raise pigs. Wayan Astiti wish is that her pregnant mother pig could bore plenty and healthy piglets.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Sebagai Seorang ibu rumah tangga yang baik Wayan Astiti tidak bisa berpangku tangan saja. Selain disibukan untuk mengurusi 2 anaknya yang sudah bersekolah wayan Astiti juga memiliki usaha beternak babi. Suami Wayan astiti ketut Rana juga memiliki kesibukan pelihara sapi kereman milik pemerintah jadi semuanya memiliki kesibukan . Kesibukan yang dimiliki Wayan Astiti memelihara 1 induk babi dan 1 pejantan. Induk babinya baru dikawinkan umur kehamilannya baru 1 bulan. Pejantan yang dimiliki Wayan astiti cukup laris , harga setiap kawin mencapai Rp.30,000,-. Setiap bulan dari hasil pejantan saja Wayan Astiti mendapatkan uang Rp.500,000,-. Oleh sebab itu wayan Astiti berani pinjam modal di Dinari sebesar Rp.1.700.000,-. Modal ini dipergunakan untuk membeli dedak padi, dedak poral dan ampas tahu. Karena ampas tahu baik untuk induk babi yang hamil. Wayan Astiti rajin mengikuti penyuluhan-penyuluhan sehingga mengetahui bagaimana memelihara babi yang benar. Harapan Wayan Astiti supaya induk babinya yang sedang hamil ini bisa melahirkan anak yang banyak dan sehat.

loans.use:
To buy feedstock and pig feed

Membeli bibit dan pakan babi

loans.name: Tafaimaa

texts.en: Tafaimaa is new to the programme: she is borrowing her first loan of US$300. This first loan will help her start her Pop Corn business. This will be the first time that she will have her own business and will plan everything on her own. She is fourty five years old and has three children. One of her kids works at Amau, and his income financially supports the entire family. Tafaimaa plans to sell Pop Corn at the Church Building during the Bingo games and also at a school during school days. One bag will be sold for 1 tala (US$0.40), and Tafaimaa hopes to sell fifty bags a day and earn US$100 a week. She is very proud to run her own business and will use the first loan to purchase the necessary initial supplies.

loans.use: Purchase of bags of corn seeds, plastic wrapping, pots, and ingredients for a popcorn business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Putri Widi

texts.id:
Nyoman Putri Widiani is a widow with 2 children, and needs more attention this time. To bare the responsibility not only as a mother, but also as a father is a very heavy burden. Nyoman Putri Widiani husband died of sickness. To fulfill household needs, every day Nyoman Putri Widiani works as a building laborer. Besides that Nyoman Putri Widiani also raised 1 fattening pig as savings for her children, since those 2 are now in Grade school. The capital to buy feed and feedstock is obtained from Dinari for Rp 1,700,000 (about US$200). Capital spending to buy feedstock was Rp 300,000 (about $35), the rest to buy animal feed and additional household expenses. Until harvest Rp600,000 (about $70) was spent, including feed. Gross income was Rp 1,200,000 (abot $140), nett Rp600,000 (about $70). From that she likes to raise 3 more fattening pigs. Her hope is to get the loan from Dinari could continue, so that her 2 children could go to higher education.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Nyoman Putri Widiani janda dengan 2 anaknya yang saat ini membutuhkan perhatian yang lebih banyak. Memikul 2 tanggung jawab dalam keluarga selain sebagai ibu juga harus bisa menjadi sosok seorang ayah sangatlah berat. Suami Nyoman Putri Widiani meninggal karena sakit. Untuk memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya tiap hari Nyoman Putri widiani bekerja sebagai buruh bangunan. Selain memiliki kesibukan sebagai buruh Nyoman Putri widiani memelihara 1 babi penggemukan untuk tabungan anaknya karena 2 anaknya sekarang duduk di bangku SD. Modal yang didapat untuk membeli bibit dan pakan didapat dari Dinari sebesar Rp.1.700,000,-. Modal yang dikeluarkan untuk membeli bibit sebesar Rp.300,000,- sisanya untuk modal pakan juga untuk tambahan pengeluaran rumah tangganya. Modal yang dikeluarkan sampai panen sebesar Rp.600,000,- ini sudah terhitung dengan pakannya. Penghasilan kotornya sebesar Rp.1.200,000,- jadi bersihnya Rp. 600,000,-. Dengan hasil yang di dapatnya ini Nyoman Putri Widiani ingin memelihara 3 babi penggemukan lagi. Harapan Nyoman Putri Widiani supaya pinjaman dari Dinari dapat berjalan terus supaya dapat menyekolahkan ke 2 anaknya kejenjang yang lebih tinggi.

loans.use:
To buy pig feed & feedstock

Membeli pakan dan bibit babi

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Mrs. Lun C., age 23, is a housewife who takes care of her two young children. Her husband works as a vehicle tire repairman. In order to expand his business and meet customer demand, she would like to borrow $1,000 to purchase an air compressor to pump tires and invest in a stock of tires to sell to his customers. They expect the expanded business will bring in $10 per day in revenue. They will use the extra income to continue to invest in the growth of the business and to save money for their children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase an air compressor and tire inventory.

loans.name: Sri Kuntari Dewi

texts.id:
Three times a day at 8:00 AM, 1:00 PM, and 5:00 PM, Sri Kuntari Dewi is feeding her raised pigs, an activity she has been doing for one year. From the permanent stall in her backyard, Sri Kuntari Dewi raised 3 mother pigs. Capital of Rp1,700,000 (about US$200) was all used to buy pig's feed. In 3 months mother pig could bore up to 10 piglets. So in 3 months she could profit Rp1,500,000 (about $170). This profit was used to buy feed for the 3 mother pigs, and partly for household needs. Although no more children to raise, Sri Kuntari Dewi still will be doing business to continue her future, and helping her husband Gusti Ngurah Windra Artika in fulfilling daily household needs. For the future Sri Kuntari Dewi like to use the loan to buy another mother pig. Because this is profitable, Sri Kuntari very much like to do it.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Tiga kali dalam sehari tepatnya Pukul 08.00 Wita,siang pukul 13.00 wita dan sore pukul 17.00 wib Sri Kuntari Dewi melakukan aktivitas yang sudah digeluti selama 1(Satu) tahun ini,yaitu memberi makan babi peliharaannya. Dengan kandang yang permanen dibelakang rumahnya,Dewi Kuntari memelihara 3(tiga) induk babi. Modal Rp.1.700.000,- ini semua dipakai untuk membeli pakan babinya. Dalam 3(tiga) bulan induk babi ini akan melahirkan 10(sepuluh) ekor anak babi.Jadi keuntungan yang didapat dalam 3 bulan sebesar Rp.1.500.000,-. Keuntungan ini digunakan untuk membeli pakan untuk ketiga induk babinya,dan sebagian untuk kebutuhan rumah tangganya.Walaupun tidak ada anak yang ditanggung lagi,Sri Kuntari Dewi tetap berusaha untuk kelanjutan masa depannya,sekaligus membantu suaminya Gusti Ngurah Windra Artika,dalam mencukupi kebutuhan sehari-hari. Untuk kedepannya sri kuntari dewi ingin pinjamannya digunakan untuk menambah induk babi lagi 1 ekor. Karena usaha ini sangat menguntungkan sehingga sri kuntari sangat senang dalam menjalaninya.

loans.use:
To buy pig feed and feedstock

Membeli bibit dan pakan babi

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Mrs.Yem S., age 42, works with her husband farming their land to grow rice and vegetables. They earn about $5 per day from the sale of their produce. They have six children. Two children work at a company as security guards, earning $5 per day each, two children are married and live separately from their parents, and two children are students.

Mrs. S. would like to borrow $1,000 to purchase a hand tractor to more efficiently work the land and produce a higher yield of crops. They plan to use the increased revenue to invest in ways to more efficiently farm their land and to finance their children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor to farm the land.

loans.name: Tamaligi

texts.en: Tamaligi runs two businesses. The first is a food stall by a local school, which operates during the week and earns her US$40 a day. The food stall sells pork buns, donuts, and ice cakes for the school children. Tamaligi’s father is a hard working man - he works at the plantation and comes home only to eat and sleep. As he runs the plantation, it is Tamaligi’s job to offer the best customer service at the market so that more people buy their crops. Two days a week (usually Friday and Saturday), she supplies taro and bananas to the market. Tamaligi is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase tools and supplies for her plantation. She is very active and is looking forward to expand her business with more loans in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals, weed killers, knives, and a wheel barrow for a plantation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Mrs. Him S., age 44, works with her husband on their farm, earning about $3 per day from selling their produce in the market. They have six children. Two children are students, one works at a garment factory earning about $3 per day, and three are married and live with their families. In order to more efficiently transport their produce to the market, she would like to request a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike. This will ensure they arrive earlier at the market with fresher produce to meet customer demand and increase sales.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport produce to the market

loans.name: Ni Made Rani

texts.id:
Besides being a tenant farmer Made Rani also owns a side business that is profitable by raising pigs. With a capital of Rp1,700,000 (about US$200), and a simple stall behind her home, made from batako and seng roof, Made Rani raised 1 mother pig and 4 fattening piglets. This stall is used to help husband Wayan Suartika to fullfil household needs. The pigs were bought from a friend who has raised pigs since a long time. With 2 children to raise, and a simple home made from batako, and while the woven bamboo kitchen was worn out, did not made Made Rani gave up on her work. That even made Rani more serious in her business. In 8 months Made Rani could profit Rp1,500,000 (about $170) from sales of piglets and 4 pig feedstock. This profit was used to re-make the kitchen and build parts of the house, so that if there were not enough pig feed, Made Rani find traditional food of: banana tree trunk and kangkoon. Made Rani is very patient in raising her pigs. Profits made will very much help family's future.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Selain sebagai petani Made Rani juga memiliki usaha sampingan yang sangat menguntungkan yaitu memelihara babi. Dengan modal Rp.1.700.000,- dan kandang yang sederhana dibelakang rumahnya,yang terbuat dari batako dan atap seng,Made Rani memelihara 1 induk babi dan 4 bibit penggemukan. Kandang ini dimanfaat untuk usaha membantu suami Wayan Suartika dalam memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya Babi ini dibeli dari sahabatnya yang sudah memelihara babi sejak lama. Denagan menanggung 2 orang anak,dan tinggal dirumah yang sederhana,terbuat dari batako,sedangkan dapur masih kumuh yang hanya terbuat dari gedeg,tidak membuat Made Rani putus asa dalam berusaha.Bahkan Rani sangat serius menjalani usaha ini.Keuntungan yang didapat sangat membantu untuk keperluan keluarga. Dalam 8 bulan Made Rani meraup keuntungan Rp.1.500.000,- yaitu keuntungan anak babi dan penjualan 4 bibit babinya. Keuntungan ini digunakan sebagian untuk membuat dapur dan membuat rumah yang masih harus dibangun sebagian.sehingga,bila pakan babi kurang Made Rani mencari pakan Tradisional berupa : batang pisang dan Kangkung.Made rani sangat telaten dalam mengurus babinya.Karena Keuntungan yang didapat sangat membantu masa depan keluarganya.

loans.use:
To buy pig feed & feedstock

Membeli pakan dan bibit babi

loans.name: Tauavae

texts.en: Tauavae I. is thirty five years old and has a child. She lives with her parents. She sells sugar cane and chips at a local school, as well as taro and bananas at a market. Tauavae only goes to the market three days a week, where she earns US$80 a day. Sometimes she sells chips and sugar cane five days a week. This is her family's only source of income, and Tauavae is grateful for the SPBD loans that have helped not only her business, but also her children’s schooling. She will use the current loan of US$700 to purchase chemicals, fertilizers, weed killers, plastic wrappings, and tools for her business.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals, fertilizers, weed killers, plastic wrapping, and tools

loans.name: Imamverdi

texts.ru:
Mr. Imamverdi Z. lives in the town of Saatly, Azerbaijan. He is 55, married and has 5 children. Imamverdi makes a living by raising cattle and selling cows on a market. He asked the local branch of NorMicro, a Kiva partner, for a $500 loan to finance business expansion. A calf costs $100 on a local market, so the loan will let Imamverdi buy 5 more animals in addition to his annual purchase.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Мр. Имамверди живет в городе Саатлы Республики Азербайджан, расположенном в Закавказье. Ему 55 лет, он женат, имеет 5-х детей. Имамверди занимается закупкой телят, их варащиванием и в дальнейшем продажей уже зрелого крупного рогатого скота на местном рынке. Таким образом он обеспачивает свою немалую семью тем необходимым минимумом, на который можно жить в условиях небогатой деревни. Но дети растут так же быстро, как растут и их потребности. Сегодня Имамверди подумывает о увеличении прибыли с его бизнеса путём вкладывания инвестиций. Он обратился в местный филиал микрокредитной организации "Нормикро" - парнёру КИВА - с просьбой предоставления ему кредита с суммой в 500 долларов для расширения бизнеса. На местном рынке цена одного телёнка 100 долларов. Так что Имамверди сможет на эту сумму кредит купить 5 телят дополнительно к тем, которые он уже закупает ежегодно.

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Shamil

texts.ru:
Shamil lives in Saatli, Azerbaijan. He is 57 years old, married and has 6 children. Shamil owns 3 dairy cows. He is the sole income earner in the family and works by milking the cows and selling the milk at the local market. It is very hard to provide for a family of 6 children and Shamil plans on increasing the production and sales of milk by increasing the number of cows.

He has turned to Normicro, a Kiva partner, with a loan request of $500 for the purchase of dairy calves. These calves cost $100 each in the local market, so Shamil can purchase 5 calves and triple his milk production. This will provide Shamil with $500 of pure profit per month.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Мр. Шамиль живет в городе Саатлы Республики Азербайджан, расположенном в Закавказье. Ему 57 лет, он женат, имеет 6-х детей. Шамиль имеет три совственные доильные коровы. Будучи единственным кормильцем в семье, он занимается доением и продажей молока на местном рынке. Обеспечивать семью с шестью детьми очень трудно и Шамиль планирует увеличить надои и продажу молока путём увеличения количества коров. Поэтому он обратился в микрокредитную организацию "Нормикро"-партнёру КИВА- с просьбой предоставить ему кредит в 500 долларов для покупки телят молочной породы. На местном рынке цена одного телёнка приравнивается 100 долларам, так что Шамиль, купив 5 телят, сможет увеличить надои молока в три раза. А это даст Шамилю 500 долларов чистой прибыли в месяц.

loans.use: To buy dairy calves

loans.name: Isgender

texts.en: Isgender S. has been engaged in this business for 10 years. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory Gubadli region, situated in the west part of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region, and is settled in Sumgayit city. He has three children and owns a mini food shop. This 47 year-old man is the only breadwinner in family. With this business he earns little money. This money is enough for only some of his family's basic needs. He has difficulty in covering other family consumption needs like medication, clothes, and school fees, etc. He needs $600 for expanding his business and improving his family's living conditions. He wants increase the number of his clients and as well as his income. He will repay the loan within 16 months.

loans.use: For expanding her business and improving her family's living conditions.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Mrs. Hem S., age 35, raises pigs, earning about $1 per day in income. Her husband works as a farmer and earns about $1 per day. They have four children, two who work at a garment factory making about $70 per month, one who is a student, and one who is married and lives in another home. In order to expand her pig raising business, she would like to borrow $500 to purchase additional piglets and pig feed. She plans to use the increased revenue to reinvest in the growth of her business and help finance her children’s education. Her husband is pictured next to their home as she was not available at the time of the photo.

loans.use: To to purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Rahim

texts.ru:
Rahim I. lives in in Saatli, Azerbaijan. He is 52 years old, is married and has 6 children. Rahim is the sole income earner for his family and earns his living by raising and selling large cattle on the local market. Every year he purchases young calves from households in local villages, grows them for 8-9 months in his household and then sells the already grown cows and bulls to local butchers.

Today, Rahim is thinking about expanding his business as the profits from his current herd are not enough to provide for the needs of 6 children. He plans to expand his annual purchase of calves by 5. For this he needs $500 to invest in his business. Rahim turned to Normicro, a KIVA partner, to receive this sum.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: Mrs. Chem S., age 35, raises ducks and sells the eggs, earning about $5 per day in revenue. Her husband works as a policeman, making about $1 per day. They have three children who are students. In order to expand her duck egg business to meet customer demand, she would like to borrow $750 to purchase more ducks to lay eggs. This will increase inventory and therefore increase income for her family. She will be better able to finance her children’s education with the increased income and provide her family with greater financial security.

loans.use: To purchase more ducks to lay eggs

loans.name: Ni Putu Artini

texts.id:
Ni Putu Artini lives in Ekasari village, West Bali. As a Balinese woman, it has been a tradition to raise pigs at home. Most of such business are side business. This is not the case for Ni Putu Artini, since this business could bring good profit for her family, if done well. Ni Putu Artini runs this pig farming with dicipline and persistence, since she wants to advance family economic situation. Before, Ni Putu Artini only raised 1 mother pig. That mother pig bore up to 12 piglets. After 4 months those piglets could be sold for Rp 250,000 (about US$28)/each. After subtracting all expenses, Ni Putu Artini could still have enough profit to support her family. With Dinari's loan, Ni Putu Artini plans to buy 1 other mother pig. She already calculated: With the mother pig ready to be impregnated, and ready to bore piglets, within the 6 month loan, Ni Putu Artini could sell the pig feedstock, and the loan could be returned timely. Ni Putu Artini plans to expand the business so that her family economic condition would improve.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Putu Artini tinggal di desa Ekasari, Bali Barat. Sebagai seorang wanita Bali, sudah menjadi tradisi untuk memelihara babi dirumah. Sebagian besar memang usaha ini digunakan sebagi usaha sampingan. Hal itu tidak berlaku bagi Ni Putu Artini, karena usaha ini baginya dapat mendatangkan keuntungan yang cukup besar bagi keluarganya jika diolah dengan baik. Ni Putu Artini mengelola usaha ternak babi dengan disiplin dan rajin, karena ia sangat ingin memajukan perekonomian keluarganya. Sebelumnya Ni Putu Artini memelihara 1 ekor induk. Dari 1 ekor induk itu bisa melahirkan anak sampai dengan 12 ekor. Setelah dipelihara selama 4 bulan, anak babi itu bisa dijual kembali dengan harga Rp. 250.000.- per ekor. Dengan dikurangi semua biaya pengeluaran yang ada untuk perawatan, Ni Putu Artini masih bisa mendapat keuntungan yang dipergunakan untuk kehidupan keluarga. Dengan pinjaman dari Dinari, Ni Putu Artini membelikannya 1 ekor induk lagi. Hal itu sudah diperhitungkannya dengan baik. Dengan kondisi induk yang sudah sudah siap dikawinkan dan akan melahirkan anak, selama jangka waktu 6 bulan pinjaman, Ni Putu Artini sudah mampu menjual bibit babi dan pinjaman bisa dikembalikan tepat waktu. Ni Putu Artini berencana mengembangkan usaha ini agar kondisi perekonomian keluarganya lebih baik dari yang sekarang.

loans.use:
To buy mother pig

Membeli induk babi

loans.name: Yamen

texts.ru:
Yamen G. lives in the suburbs of Saatli, Azerbaijan. Yamen, 43, shares a small village house with her elderly parents. Yamen’s entire income comes from selling milk from a milking cow she purchased 2 years ago. The cow yields 7-8 liters of milk daily, which cost about $1.30 on the local market. The money is not enough to sustain Yamen and her parents, so Yamen turned to NorMicro, a Kiva partner, for help. She asks for $500 loan to purchase a milking calf. In 8 months, Yamen will be able to double her earnings from milk sales.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Гурбанова Ямен живет в пригороде Саатлы Республики Азербайджан, расположенном в Южном Кавказе. Ей 43 года и она живёт в месте с её родителями в деревенском домике, обеспечивая как можно их старость. Она имеет доход, очень низкий, с коровы, которую они купили 2 года тому назад, продавая молоко на местном рынке. Ежедневный надой с коровы составляет 7-8 литров, т.е. приблизительно 1 доллар и 30 центов. Этого конечно не хватает на удовлетворение нужд семьи. В настоящее время Ямен обратилась в микро кредитную организацию "Нормикро" - партнёру КИВА с заявлением о предоставлении ей кредита на сумму $500 для покупки телёнка дойной породы. Таким образом через 8 месяцев она планирует увеличить свой доход от продажи молока на 100 процентов.

loans.use: To buy a milking calf

loans.name: Loas

texts.en: Mrs. Loas K., age 29, sells clothes in the market, earning about $5 per day in revenue. Her husband works as a moto-taxi driver, also earning about $5 per day. They have two children who are students. In order to meet her customers’ demands for more fashionable clothing, she would like to borrow $300 to increase her inventory. This will increase her revenue in the long term and allow her to better finance her children’s education. Mrs. Loas K. was not home at the time this photo was taken, so her husband is pictured instead on his moto-taxi.

loans.use: To purchase more fashionable clothes for her clothing business

loans.name: Shamama

texts.ru:
Shamama P. lives in Saatli, Azerbaijan located in the Southern Caucasus. She is 58 years old, married and has 5 children. Her family is large, has few resources and it is getting increasingly harder to support it with the high rates of unemployment. The only hope is the household’s plot of land and a small herd of sheep.

Once a year Shamama together with her husband sells sheep at the local market, and uses part of the earnings to purchase lambs and the rest for meeting the most important needs of the family. Her grandson helps in the business as well (see photo). Of course the profits from the sale of such a small herd are small and investment is needed to increase them. Shamama has applied for a loan with Normicor, a KIVA partner. After receiving a loan she plans to use it to expand the number of sheep in her herd and to increase profits from their sales. This will allow her to provide her children with an education at the local school.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Шамама Пирвердиева живет в городе Саатлы Республики Азербайджан, расположенном в Южном Кавказе. Ей 58 лет, она замужем, имеет 5-х детей. Семья большая, малообеспеченная и содержать её в условиях безработицы становится всё трудней. Единственная надежда на приусадебный участок и на очень маленькое стадо овец. Раз в году Шамама вместе с мужем продают овец на местном базаре, часть вырученных денег тратят на покупку ягнят, остальную часть - на удовлетворение самых насущных потребностей семьи. Так же ей в этом бизнесе помогает её внук (см. фото). Конечно, доход с продажи столь малого по численности стада очень мал и для его увеличения необходимы некоторые инвестиции. Поэтому Шамама обратилась с заявлением для получения кредита в микро кредитную организацию "Нормикро" - партнёру КИВА - для получения кредита. После получения кредита она планирует использовать его для расширения численности овец в стаде и получить более высокий доход от их продажи, что позволит ей обеспечить её детей обучением в местной школе.

loans.use: To increase number of sheep

loans.name: Ni Luh Roteh

texts.id:
Ni Luh Roteh and husband Putu Widya live in a just get by economy. Ni Luh Roteh has 3 children, but only one is still their responsibility, because the other two are married, and live with their own families. To support household expenses, Ni Luh Roteh raise 1 mother pig and 1 fattening piglet. Capital for pig's feed Ni Luh Roteh obtains a loan from Dinari for Rp 1,400,000 (about US$155). Ni Luh Roteh stall condition is simple, bamboo stall. For feeding Ni Luh Roteh not only used rice shell clippings. Her pig's feed are mixed with cooked talas leaves, and coconut leftover after cooked for its oil. Ni Luh Roteh mother pig is pregnant, and soon will bore piglets. Once born, they would be raised for 3 months. Ni Luh Roteh hope is that her business of mother pig and fattening piglets could be successful, and gave good profit, that could repair her house which is still a bamboo hut.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Luh Roteh dan suaminya Putu Widya hidup dalam ekonomi yang pas-pasan. Ni Luh Roteh memiliki anak 3 orang, tetapi masih ada satu anaknya yang menjadi tanggungan karena dua anaknya sudah menikah dan tinggal dengan keluarganya masing – masing. Untuk mencukupi semua pengeluaran rumah tangganya Ni Luh Roteh memelihara 1 induk dan 1 babi penggemukan. Untuk modal pakannya Ni Luh Roteh mendapat pinjaman dari Dinari sebesar Rp.1.400.000,- . Kondisi kandang Ni Luh Roteh sederhana memakai kandang bambu.Untuk makanannya Ni Luh Roteh tidak memakai dedak saja. Makanan babinya dicampur dengan daun talas yang sudah dimasak juga ampas dari sisa kelapa yang dipakai minyak.. Kondisi induk babi Ni Luh Roteh sudah hamil dan beberapa saat lagi akan melahirkan. Bibit babi untuk penggemukkan dipelihara selama 3 bulan. Harapan Ni Luh Roteh supaya induk babi dan babi penggemukannya bisa berhasil dan memperoleh keuntungan yang banyak serta bisa memperbaiki rumahnya yang sekarang masih gubuk bambu.

loans.use:
To buy pig's feed

Membeli pakan ternak

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Siram

texts.id:
Ni Nyoman Siram and her husband Putu Suardana the two of them lives in a home, since all children have their own household. The house condition of Nyoman Siram is semi permanent from batako walls, and cement floor. Although in advanced age, Ni Nyoman Siram still has the will to advance her family's well being. Therefore Nyoman Siram borrowed Rp1,400,000 (about US$155) from Dinari. She use that capital to buy animal feed like rice shell clippings and konsentrat (local brand). At this time Nyoman Siram's mother pig bore 6 piglets. With the system of raising for 3 months (to serve roasted piglet) her capital would circle fast, so that Ni Nyoman Siram could pay the loan on time, and profit could be used to pay for daily living expenses. Ni Nyoman Siram likes this business, therefore Ni Nyoman Siram is doing it happily. Ni Nyoman Siram hopes that the loan for Dinari could succeed, so that her business could be expanded.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Nyoman Siram dan suaminya Putu Suardana tinggal berdua di rumahnya karena semua anaknya sudah berumah tangga. Kondisi rumah Nyoman Siram semi permanen yang terbuat dari dinding batako dan lantai semen. Walaupun sudah tua, Ni Nyoman Siram tetap mempunyai semangat untuk meningkatkan kesejahteraan keluarganya . Oleh sebab itu Nyoman Siram meminjam modal di Dinari sebesar Rp. 1.400.000,-. Modal yang didapat untuk membeli pakan seperti dedak dan konsentrat. Saat ini induk babi Nyoman Siram melahirkan anak 6 ekor. Dengan sistem pemeliharaan selama 3 bulan ( untuk melayani babi guling ) semua modalnya akan berputar dengan cepat sehingga Ni Nyoman Siram bisa membayar pinjaman tepat waktu dan keuntungan yang didapat bisa digunakan untuk kebutuhan sehari - hari. Ni Nyoman Siram sangat menyenangi usahanya ini karenanya Ni Nyoman Siram melakukannya dengan senang hati . Harapan Ni Nyoman Siram supaya pinjaman dari Dinari akan berkesinambungan sehingga usahanya bisa dikembangkan.

loans.use:
To buy pig feed

Membeli pakan babi

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Mrs. Phan S. Y., age 27, raises pigs on her land. Her husband, 30, is a farmer who earns $2 per day selling his produce. They have one small child who is too young attend school. In order to grow her business and increase revenue, she would like to request a loan of $250 to purchase additional piglets to raise and sell at the market. Increasing her inventory will meet growing customer demand and allow her to save money for the future. Her husband is pictured in front of her pigsty because she was not available at the time of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell.

loans.name: Ni Komang Suarniti

texts.id:
Although no more children to raise, Ni Komang Suarniti still has to do business for her livelihood. With a loan of Rp1,400,000 (about US$155) Komang Suarniti bought 2 pig feedstock. So, now she raises 4 pigs. The stalls to raise the pigs are simple, from bamboo walls and cement floor. Besides feedstock, Rp400,000 (about $44) is used to buy pig's feed. Sometimes pig feed are mixed with traditional feed, like banana trunk, lantoro leaves and kangkoong. The house she lives with husband Ketut Kaler are owned. Besides farming, Ni Komang Suarniti husband's also sells cow's feed, like grass, that are plentiful in their yard. Ketut Kaler already has many customers. 1 bundle of grass was sold for Rp10,000 ($1.10). Ketut Kaler also often helps his wife feeding the pigs. All profit are used to pay for daily needs, and also expanding the pig business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Walaupun sudah tidak menanggung anak, Ni Komang Suarniti tetap berusaha untuk kelanjutan hidupnya. Dengan modal pinjaman Rp.1.400.000,- Komang Suarniti membeli bibit babi sebanyak 2 ekor. Jadi babi yang dipelihara sekarang menjadi 4 ekor. Kandang yang dimiliki untuk memelihara babinya sangat sederhana, terbuat dari dinding bambu dan lantai semen. Selain membeli bibit babi, uang sejumlah Rp. 400.000,- digunakan untuk membeli pakan. Kadang - kadang pemberian pakan babi diselingi dengan makanan tradisional seperti: batang pisang, daun lantoro dan kangkung. Rumah yang dihuni sekarang bersama suaminya, Ketut Kaler, adalah rumah milik sendiri. Selain bertani, suami Ni Komang Suarniti juga menjual pakan sapi yang berupa rumput – rumputan yang banyak ditanam di pekarangan rumahnya. I Ketut Kaler sudah banyak memiliki langgana. 1 ikat rumput dijual Rp.10.000,- Ketut Kaler juga sering membantu istrinya memberi makan babinya. Semua keuntungan yang didapat digunakan untuk kebutuhan sehari-hari dan juga untuk pengembangan usaha babinya.

loans.use:
To buy feedstock and pig feed

Membeli pakan dan ternak babi

loans.name: Rafael

texts.en:
F. Rafael was born in the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory Agdam region, situated in the western part of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. He is 45 years old and the father of three children. He settled with his family in Sumgait city in 1993.

Right now, he lives with his family in Sumgayit city, situated in the eastern part of Azerbaijan. He started his business in 1996. He began his business with $200.

He started selling a small variety of shoes. With this small business and only $200 in working capital, he could hardly earn enough money to meet his family's food and important consumption needs.

Having borrowed the loan amount of $500 from Normicro, he rented a shop. The loans were paid back in a timely manner.

Rafael wants expand his business and to begin selling a different variety of clothes. He wants a $900 loan. He hopes to eventually expand his business and improve the living conditions of his family. He will repay his loan on a monthly basis.

loans.use: To expand his business and to begin selling a different variety of clothes

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim R., age 31, is a widow who works as a farmer earning about $1.50 each day. She has one child who is a student. In order to increase her business revenue, she would like to request a loan of $300 to purchase fertilizer and seeds for her crop cultivation and use the remainder of the loan to buy piglets to raise and sell at the market. She hopes this will increase her income enough to help finance her child’s education and give them a more dependable income stream.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds for farming, and piglets to raise

loans.name: Gusti Ayu Putu Karti

texts.id:
Gusti Ayu Putu Kartini with husband and 2 children still stays in her brother's house. To fullfill family needs Gusti Ayu Putu Kartini became a pig farmer. Loan from Dinari organization for Rp1,700,000 (about US$190) will be used to buy 2 sorts of local balinese piglets for Rp500,000 (about $55) for both. Every morning Gusti Ayu Putu Kartini prepared the food for the 2 piglets. In the evenings Gusti Ayu Putu Kartini and children also feed the piglets. Feed expenses for 3 months could reach Rp250,000 (about $28). After 3 months those piglets could be sold for Rp1,300,000 (about $143). Nett profit of 3 months are about Rp500,000 (about $55). With this she could support her husband's income as a tenant farmer, and to pay for childrens education expenses. Gusti Ayu Putu Kartini plans to expand her business, so that Gusti Ayu could afford her own accomodation.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Gusti Ayu Putu Kartini berserta suami dan kedua orang anaknya tinggal satu rumah dan masih menumpang pada saudaranya.Untuk mencukupi keluarganya Gusti Ayu Kartini mempunyai kegiatan pokok yaitu beternak babi. Dengan pinjaman dari Yayasan DINARI sebersar Rp.1.700.000,- dipergunakan untuk membeli 2 babi jenis lokal Bali dengan harga Rp.500.000,- keduanya. Setiap pagi Gusti Ayu Kartini menyiapkan pakan untuk kedua babinya. Sedang sore harinya Gusti Ayu Krtini dibantu oleh kedua orang anaknya dalam memberikan pakan babinya. Biaya pakan selama 3 bulan dapat mencapai Rp. 250.000,- Selama 3 bulan dipelihara kemudian babi dijual dengan harga Rp.1.300.000,- semuanya. Keuntungan bersih selama 3 bulan dapat mencapai Rp.500.000,- Dengan keuntungan hasil beternaknya dapat membantu pendapatan suaminya yang sebagai petani, dan untuk biaya sekolah anak-anaknya. Gusti Ayu Putu Kartini mempunyai rencana untuk mengembangkan usahanya dan dari usahanya itu Gusti Ayu akan mampu memiliki tempat tinggal sendiri.

loans.use:
To buy pig feedstock

Membeli bibit babi

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Mrs. Pich S., age 80, is a widow and is too old to work. She has four children: one works at a carpentry store, earning around $7 each day; one works at a garment factory earning around $100 per month; and two stay at home with their children. She would like to request a loan of $500 to purchase a calf for her children to raise and then sell after 6 months to enable her to earn additional income to support her and her family. She is pictured with her son in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a calf to raise and resell

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Mrs. Heang C. E., age 35, is a farmer. Her husband buys and sells recyclable products, earning about $4.80 per day. They have three children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to increase the inventory of recyclable items her husband can sell and to buy an additional piece of farmland to increase her crop output. She believes both these actions will lead to an increase in revenue and income to support the family and pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase farmland, plus recyclable materials to resell

loans.name: Sit

texts.en: Mrs. Sit S., age 41, works with her husband as a broker to buy and sell rubber, together earning about $3.25 per day in profits. They have two children who are students. In order to increase her supply of rubber, she would like to request a loan of $400 to purchase an additional stock of rubber from a plantation to sell to the wholesalers. Increasing her inventory will raise revenue and thereby increase the income used to support her children’s education and family's welfare.

loans.use: To purchase rubber for resale

loans.name: Lina Alberto

texts.pt:
Lina lives with her husband and 6 school age children. She joined the credit program in 2000. Her first loan was of 24$. Her business of selling corn has been growing. With this loan she plans on buying more corn and paying for delivery. She helps her husband with home expenses. Lina hopes to improve her home with income from the business.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Lina vive maritalmente com um homem de quem tem 6 filhos. Todos estao em idade escolar.Lina entrou para o programa de credito do Fundo de Desenvolvimento da Mulher em 2000, como membro de um grupo solidaria que na altura se juntou para tomar tomar dinheiro emprestado. O primeiro valor que ela recebeu nessa altura foi de $24.O negocio dela foi crescendo, ela agora vende milho em sacos. O dinheiro que ela vai tomar e para poder comprar mais sacos de milho e pagar pelo transporte dos mesmos pois que o local onde adquir o milho e numa outra Provincia.O negocio esta a corre-lhe bem. Ela apoia o marido nas despesas da casa e comparticipa no pagamento da escola para os filhos ,pois que todos eles estao em idade escolar.Ela pensa ampliar a sua residencia com os lucros do negocio.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Hezi

texts.en: Mr. Hazi Hemzeyiv is a low income person which makes him vulnerable. He is 25 years old and lives in Sumgayit city in the north-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic. He is married and has two children. He is a driver of public transportation. He began his business five years ago and it has allowed him to support his family. In 2002 Hezi bought a mini bus. This car was often demanding repair. His minibus was old and he planned to sell it and to buy a new one. He eventually bought a new vehicle to use for his public transportation service. This bus is very comfortable and his passengers are very satisfied, but there not any bus stations near his house. He wants he borrow $600 to build a garage near his house. He hopes eventually to expand his business and improve the living conditions of his family. He will repay this loan on a monthly basis.

loans.use: To build a garage near his house.

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en: Mrs. Sreng C., age 47, is a widow and sells grocery products in the market, earning up to $10 per day in revenue. She has three children; one child sells food and rice on the roadside, making about $1.50 each day in profit, and two children work as waiters in a restaurant. In order to expand her inventory of grocery items to meet her clients’ demands, she would like to borrow $1,200 to purchase a greater variety of products to resell.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of grocery products to increase inventory

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Sreng Chanthol has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo S., age 48, sells homemade desserts on the roadside of her village, earning about $7.30 per day in revenue. Her husband, age 62, is too old to work. They have six children, three who are students and three who are married and live separately from the family. In order to grow her business and meet customer demand, she would like to request a loan of $1,200 to buy products needed to make more desserts to increase her inventory. She believes that having more inventory to meet her growing customer demand will increase revenue and make her better able to finance her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make desserts to sell

loans.name: Fiel Da Rocha Fernan

texts.pt:
Fiel da Rocha Fernando is not married but he lives with his girlfriend with whom he has 2 children. He works for the government as a clerk. H e joined the credit program in 2005, with the loans he has been able to buy home appliances. His girlfriend has her own small business. With this loan he wants to buy construction material to improve his home. He is able to support his family and the loans have been very useful.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Fiel da Rocha Fernando, solteiro, vive maritalmente com uma mulher com quem tem 2 filhos. Ele e funcionario numa instituicao estatal. E escriturario. Ele entrou para o programa de credito em 2005. Com o valor dos emprestimos nessa altura conseguiu comprar electrodomesticos para a sua casa.A sua esposa faz pequenos negocios, mas ele nao faz negocio nenhum. O emprestimo dele e de consumo. Com o emprestimo actual ele quer comprar material de construcao para poder construir uma casa feita de material convencional, pois que actualmente vive numa casa de pau a pique. Os seus dois filhos estao a estudar.Ele consegue sustentar a sua familia sem ggrandes problemas, pois que o emprestimo tem-lhe sido muito util.

loans.use: Buy construction material

loans.name: Try

texts.en: Mrs. Try M., age 24, works with her husband to make chopping boards to sell to wholesalers, earning about $3 per day. They have three children, two of whom are students and one of whom is too young to attend school. In order to increase the number of cutting boards they can make, she would like to request a loan of $200 to purchase additional wood, saws, and other tools for their business. Selling these additional cutting boards will increase revenue and help pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make chopping boards

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Try Meit has paid back this Kiva loan early.

Thank your for your support. Thanks to lenders like you, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to invest into their small businesses and families. We hope that you will continue your support  and reinvest your loan in another entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mrs. Cheng S., age 41, is a farmer. Her husband works as a driver. They have three children, and her mother also lives with them. Two of her children are students, and one is employed at a garment factory earning about $1.60 per day. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a horse and cart for her husband to operate as a business. He can move produce to markets and transport people between villages, increasing their income by $2.50 per day. This will improve quality of life for the family and help finance their children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase a horse and cart for her husband to operate as a driver

loans.name: Olivia Maria

texts.pt:
Olivia is a single mother, she lives with her children. She is now joining the credit program. She wants to use this loan to increase her inventory of clothes. She sells these from a cart. Olivia does this work in order to provide for her children, in the future she wants to be able to build a home for her family.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Olivia e mae solteira e tem 3 filhos. Ela vive soziha com os seus 3 filhos. Esta entrando pela promeira vez no programa de credito. Ela quer usar o dinheiro do emprestimo para aumentar as pecas de vestuario para a venD.. Ela e vendedora ambulante. Ela iniciou este negocio para poder melhorar a sua viD. e a dos seus filhos.No futuro se o negocio crescer e consguir lucros, ela pensa construir uma casa para si e para os seus filhos.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Phung Thi Thanh

texts.vi:
Ms Phùng Thị Thanh is 44 years old. She owns a clothing store in Xuân Hòa village (in the township of Phúc Yên). She serves her customers very well. She makes them feel comfortable coming to her store, knowing that they will get excellent advice from her in selecting the clothes that would suit their style. On top of that, she is so friendly, warm and always has a smile on her face. Her 7 year experience in the clothing business helps her provide excellent advice to her customers of all types. She has 2 children, aged 22 and 18. Her husband, Phạm Duy Tân, has retired from the work force due to his disability. He lends her a good hand in running the store. He picks up the merchandise in Hà Nội, Móng Cái and transports back to the store. Ms Hà is the member of the TYM fund for the last 5 years. This time she requests a loan of 625 USD to buy more clothes. She hopes to be able to qualify for bigger loans from TYM fund in the future.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Chị Phùng Thị Thanh Hà, 44 tuổi, có một cửa hàng quần áo tại phường Xuân Hòa, thị xã Phúc Yên. Những khách hàng có dịp đến đây đều luôn nhớ tới thái độ vui vẻ, nhiệt tình cùng nụ cười luôn thường trực trên khuôn mặt của bà chủ cửa hàng. Khách đến mua hàng thường được tư vấn về việc nên mua gì, mặc gì cho đẹp, cho phù hợp với lứa tuổi. Kinh nghiệm 7 năm trong việc kinh doanh quần áo giúp chị có những lời khuyên hợp lý cho mọi loại khách hàng. Chị Hà hiện có hai người con 22 và 18 tuổi. Chồng chị, anh Phạm Duy Tân, một công nhân về nghỉ mất sức, là người trợ giúp tích cực cho công việc kinh doanh của vợ. Anh chính là người đi lấy hàng từ Hà Nội, Móng Cái về cho vợ bán. Là thành viên năm thứ 5 của Quỹ Tình thương, chị Hà đang xin vay 625 USD để tăng lượng hàng nhập về. Chị mong muốn trong tương lai sẽ được vay những mức vốn lớn hơn từ Quỹ.

loans.use: to buy clothes for her shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Mrs. Lach K., age 28, works with her husband to manufacture chopping boards to sell to wholesalers, earning about $4 per day together. They have one child who is too young to attend school. In order to increase their output, she would like to request a loan of $600 to purchase more wood and saws. She anticipates that the increased output will raise revenue and provide more income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase wood and saws to make chopping boards

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Your Kiva loan has been paid back ahead of time.

Thanks to your support of entrepreneurs like Lach Kung, small businesses around the world have access to low-interest loans to help their business.

We hope you will continue loaning through Kiva and CREDIT MFI.

Best regards,
Isadora Tang
Kiva Fellow,
Cambodia

loans.name: Dinh Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Đinh Thị Tuyết is 41 years old. She runs a restaurant near the University (pedagogy). Most of her clientele are university students. Everyday her restaurant serves about 400 customers. With such a high volume of sales, her husband and their 2 children help running the place. She also hires 3 employees. Despite the hard work, the profit is pretty good. Every month, Ms Tuyết brings home 400 USD after expenses. Not only this business helps securing her family financial, it also provides stable work for her family members and others as well. Recently, she had expanded her business into room renting for students. She has 20 rooms for rent to satisfy the needs of the university students. She is requesting a loan of 575 USD to stock up her food stand and invest more in her room renting business

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Chị Đinh Thị Tuyết, 41 tuổi, bán hàng ăn được gần 10 năm. Ở gần trường Đại học sư phạm 2, khách hàng của chị phần lớn là sinh viên. Mỗi ngày cửa hàng đón tiếp khoảng 400 khách. Với một lượng khách đông đảo như vậy, ngoài sự phụ giúp của chồng và hai con, chị Tuyết còn thuê thêm 3 nhân công bên ngoài. Công việc tuy vất vả nhưng hiệu quả kinh tế mang lại rất cao. Trừ chi phí cho thực phẩm và công lao động, hàng tháng chị Tuyết thu về khoảng 400 USD. Việc bán hàng ăn không những giúp gia đình có thu nhập cao mà còn tạo việc làm cho mọi người trong gia đình. Gần đây chị mới xây 20 phòng trọ cho những sinh viên có nhu cầu đến thuê. Chị đang làm đơn xin vay 575 USD để mua thực phẩm làm thức ăn, bổ sung cho số vốn kinh doanh vừa dùng đầu tư cho việc xây phòng trọ.

loans.use: buy food for her restaurant

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi Thuy

texts.vi:
The neighborhood around the University of Hà Nội, Xuân Hòa district, offers a lot of opportunities for business because of its population density. There are a lot of restaurants and rooms for rent to accommodate those university students. Apart from the need for food, living space and cultural exchange, getting on line is an undeniable necessity for the young crowd. Based on her market study, Ms Nguyễn Thị Thúy opened an internet cafe in 2003. Ms Thúy is 57 years old, her 3 children are all grown up and have a job so she has to hire 2 employees to help her run the internet cafe. Having a good, friendly customer service keeps the cafe busy. Her husband, a retired military officer, helps her out when she is busy. The revenue for the internet cafe is about 350 USD / month minus salaries for the 2 employees at 50 USD / month. Ms Thúy requests a loan of 575 USD to buy new equipment for her internet cafe.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Là một địa bàn rất thuận lợi cho việc phát triển kinh tế (gần trường Đại học sư phạm Hà Nội 2) nên trên địa bàn phường Xuân Hòa có rất nhiều những cửa hàng ăn, phòng trọ. Bên cạnh nhu cầu về ăn ở, việc giao lưu, trao đổi, tìm hiểu thông tin qua mạng dần trở thành một nhu cầu không thể thiếu được của giới trẻ. Theo xu hướng chung của thị thường, chị Nguyễn Thị Thúy V. đã mở quán internet vào năm 2003. 57 tuổi, 3 con đều có việc làm độc lập nên chị V. phải thuê thêm 2 nhân công hỗ trợ cho việc trông nom cửa hàng. Luôn giữ thái độ vui, vẻ hòa nhã với mọi người nên cửa hàng của chị lúc nào cũng đông khách. Chồng chị, một cán bộ quân đội đã nghỉ hưu đôi khi cũng giúp trông hàng khi chị có việc bận. Thu nhập từ cửa hàng là khoảng 300 USD/tháng trong đó lương của nhân công là 50 USD cho mỗi người. Chị V. đang xin vay 575 USD để đầu tư mua thêm máy mới cho cửa hàng.

loans.use: to buy computers

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Namig

texts.en:
F. Namig is a refugee from the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory Agdam region, situated in the western part of the Azerbaijan Republic since 1993.

He began his business with $300 in 1999. He started selling a small variety of shoes. With this small business and only $300 in working capital, he could hardly earn enough money to meet his family's food and important consumption needs. He had difficulty covering other family consumption needs for medication, clothes, school, etc.

In 2005, after borrowing $400 from Normicro, Namig was able to expand his business and increase the income of his business and improve his family's livelihood.

Now, he needs a $700 loan in order to further develop his business, to buy other shoes and goods to increase his business and to improve his family’s living conditions with this additional income.

loans.use: To buy other shoes and goods to increase his business

loans.name: Poeun

texts.en: Mrs. Poeun I., age 48, runs a butcher stand at the market, earning about $7.30 per day in revenue. Her husband is also a butcher and helps at the stand. They have four children, two of whom work in a garment factory making about $120 per month and two of whom are married and have moved away from home. She would like to request a loan of $1,200 to increase her inventory of pork and beef to meet her customers’ growing demands and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory of meat

loans.name: Remigio Julio

texts.pt:
Remigio is not married but lives with his girlfriend with whom he has 3 small children. He joined the credit program in 2005 when he sold clothes. As his business grew he also started to sell kitchenware. He works with his girlfriend and all his children are in school. In the future Remigio plans on building a home.
