Pertenece al grupo Niño de Atocha 2 y las otras integrantes del grupo son: Leydi Domínguez Gra. (Venta de zapatos por catálogos) Ambas esperan con sus préstamos invertir comprando mayor cantidad de productos del rubro de cada una para de esta forma aumentar sus ventas.

loans.use: Increase sale of clothing, shoes, and cosmetics

loans.name: Selesitina

texts.en: Selestina believes that the more you plant and grow, the more you get. She helps to run a 6-acre taro plantation which is looked after by her husband and 4 laborers. Most of her family has moved overseas, but she has no plans of joining them, because she can financially get by with the income that she earns at the taro plantation. She sells her produce twice a month at a market, where she makes US$300-400 each time. She also has a contract to sell taro in American Samoa once a month. Selestina is asking for a loan of US$300 to be able to purchase fertilizers, spades, and knives for her plantation.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers, spades, and knives for a plantation

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en: Nestor is a single man. He has been in the photography business since 1998. This loan is his second one with HELP Africa . He needs US$ 400 to equip a studio where people will come to  have their pictures taken. Nestor  will be able to make  profit as there  are  few photographers  in the area. He will be  able to make profit and pay back his loan on time, just as he did in the past.

loans.use: To buy more photo-studio equipment

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for HELP Africa - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
Doña Marizta is 33 years old, has 2 children and her husband works as a janitor in a building in the town of San Cristóbal. She sells tacos (tipical food from the region) from a borrowed stand near her home. She belongs to the group Niño de Atocha 3 together with doña Blanca Torres Ruiz, and doña Olga Parroquia García, who sell shoes from a catalogue, doña María Moreno Guillen, who prepares and sells tamales as a street vendor, and doña Susana López Hernández, who sells fruits, vegetables, and flowers. The loan will be used to buy products so each of their businesses may increase the sales.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer

MARITZA, se dedica a la venta de tacos (alimento típico de la zona) en un local que le prestan cerca de su domicilio , ella tiene 33 años , 2 hijos su esposo trabaja como conserje en un edificio en la ciudad de San Cristóbal Ella pertenece al grupo Niño de Atocha 3 junto con doña Blanca Torres Ruiz (venta de zapatos por catálogo) y doña Olga Parroquia García (venta zapatos por catálogo) y doña María Moreno Guillen (hace y vende tamales como vendedor ambulante ) y finalmente Susana López Hernández (vende frutas, verduras y flores) Cada una de ellas espera incrementar las compras de sus productos para vender mas con la ayuda del préstamo obtenido

loans.use: INCREASE PRODUCTION AND SALE OF TIPICAL FOOD

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy fruit to make juice for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for HELP Africa - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maria Elsa

texts.es:
Doña Maria Elsa is 32 years old, married, and her husband works as a chauffeur in the public transportation system and she sells clothes in her home. She buys the garments in a place called la Mesilla, located on the border with Guatemala, where she finds variety and good prices. She belongs to the group Reina 5 and the other members are doña Maria Paula R. Mazariegos, who sells chicken meat in her home and doña Irma Martínez Pérez, who sells delicacies from outside her house. The loan will be used by Maria Elsa to buy more clothes on her next trip to la Mesilla and that way she will increase her sales. Marisa and Irma will adapt a space in their home to display their products in a more attractive way.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer

MARIA ELSA, tiene 32 años, es casada su esposo trabaja como chofer de locomoción colectiva y ella se dedica a la venta de ropa en su casa. La compra en la frontera con Guatemala en un lugar llamado la Mesilla donde encuentra gran variedad de surtido y precios. Pertenece al grupo Reina 5 y las otras integrantes son: Maria Paula R. Mazariegos (venta de pollos trozados en su casa) y doña Irma Martínez Pérez (vende antojitos en la puerta de sus casa). Con el préstamo esperan invertir Maria Elsa comprando mas ropa en su próximo viaje a la Mesilla para aumentar sus ventas y Marisa e Irma adaptaran un lugar en su casa para exhibir mejor sus productos.

loans.use: BUY MORE PRODUCTS TO INCREASE SALE OF CLOTHING

loans.name: Maria Elisa

texts.es:
Doña Maria Elisa is 38 years old, has 2 children and her husband works at a contruction site. She sells timber in the town of Tuxtla Gutiérrez with some distribuitors and also from her home. She belongs to the group Reina 5 together with doña Mauricia García Méndez, who sells food from a stand and doña Guadalupe T. Hernández, who sells clothes from her home. With the loan they will buy implements to condition their houses and promote the sale of their products.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

MARIA E., tiene 38 años, 2 hijos, su esposo trabaja en las obras de una construcción, ella se dedica a la venta de maderas en la ciudad de Tuxtla Gutiérrez con unos distribuidores y también en su casa. Pertenece al grupo Reina 5 junto con doña Mauricio García Méndez (vende comida en un local día por medio) y doña Guadalupe T. Hernández (venta de ropa en su casa). Con el préstamo compraran implementos para acondicionar sus casas y promocionar y vender mejor sus productos.

loans.use: PROMOTE SALE OF TIMBER

loans.name: Mama

texts.en:
Mama F. is married and a mum of four children. She is requesting a loan of US$ 200 to buy charcoal for domestic use for re-sale. There is nobody else selling charcoal in her area. Any time that she has enough in stock, people come running for the product.

As there is a huge demand, Mama F. would like to expand her business and make more profit, pay back her loan, and use part of her profit to buy food and soap for her four children.

Mama F. is a member of the group “ENTENTE”, a women's group affiliated to HELP Africa since 2003.

loans.use: buy charcoal for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for HELP Africa - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Lesy Belmalin

texts.es:
I have a small business selling fried chicken and fried potatoes. This business has been located in my home for five years. My sales are very good since my clients like the flavor of my chickens. With the business I help my family with monthly expenses that we have with our children.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

I have a small business of the sale of fried chicken and chipses. This business this hubicado in my house for 5 years. My sales are very good since my clients lesgusta the flavor of my chickens. With this business I help to my family with monthly expenses that we have with our children.

loans.use: purchase of chickens, potatoes, onion, garlic, spices etc

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
Doña Celia sells soft drinks from her house, she is 44 years old and lives with her partner who works as a talachero, fixing flat tyres, and they have 3 children. She belongs to the group Leopoldo 7 together with doña Irene Navarro S., who manufactures and sells different kinds of cheese and doña Petrona del Socorro Navarro, who sells clothes. They plan to invest the loan to purchase raw materials for the production of cheese. Doña Celia, doña Irene and doña Petrona are also planning to buy more inexpensive clothes at la Mesilla and that way increase their sales and earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer

CELIA , se dedica a la venta de refrescos en su casa tiene 44 años y vive en unión libre su pareja trabaja como talachero ( coloca parches en las llantas pinchadas) tienen 3 hijos, Ella pertenece al grupo Leopoldo 7 junto con doña Irene Navarro S.(hace y vende quesos y quesillos) y doña Petrona del Socorro Navarro (venta de ropa)Con el préstamo esperan invertir en comprar materias primas para la producción de sus negocios doña Celia y doña Irene y doña Petrona ira a la Mesilla a comprar ropa mas económica y así todas aumentaran sus ventas.

loans.use: BUY RAW MATERIALS TO INCREASE PRODUCTION AND SALE OF CHEESE

loans.name: Marina Victoria

texts.en:
Since she was very young Marina had to face great adversities and until now, thanks to her strength of character, she has been able to overcome them. One of the greatest challenges and battles that she had to take on was raising her children, alone with out any help, after they were abandoned by her partner. This man decided to run away more than 8 years ago, leaving them completely abandoned. Regardless, Marina has known how to overcome adversity and to continue moving forward with the help of her family. Thanks to this she was able to open a small grocery store in her house. This business is helping her to provide for the studies of her children and to cover the expenses of the home.

Now she is beginning to face new challenges due to the decision of her children to undertake studies in the university of her small city. This decision increases Marina’s happiness and also her worry because she has to find a way to cover the increased expenses that are her children are going to generate over time. It is for this reason that Marina asks for the sum of $200 in order to put a juice maker in her store and increase income. With your help and the strength and diligence of a mother we can convert her dreams into reality.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein.

Doña Marina desde muy joven tuvo que pasar por muchas adversidades en la vida y hasta ahora gracias a su entereza ha podido sobrellevarlas.Una de las más grandes adversidades y luchas que tuvo que asumir sola sin ninguna ayuda es la crianza de sus hijos frente al abandono de su pareja, ya que este sujeto decidió huir hace más de 8 años y dejó a sus hijos en completo abandono.Sin embargo, ha sabido sobreponerse y salir adelante con el apoyo de su familia, gracias a ello pudo abrir una pequeña bodega en su casa y ésta le ha ayudado a solventar los estudios de sus hijos y los gastos de su hogar.Ahora comienza a tener nuevos retos debido a la decisión de sus hijos de emprender una carrera universitaria en su pequeña ciudad. Esta decisión acrecenta la felicidad y preocupación de Marina porque tiene que empezar a ver la forma de solventar los gastos que irán generando sus hijos con el transcurso del tiempo.Es por ello que solicita la suma de 200 dólares para implementar una juguería en su pequeña tienda con el fin de obtener mayores ingresos.Con tu colaboración y el esfuerzo de esta diligente madre podremos convertir sus anhelos en realidad

loans.use: Purchase of parts for the installation of a juice maker in her small store.

loans.name: Idis Sonay

texts.en:
Idis Sonay H. R. has been selling clothes from her house for 5 years. She sells shirts, sport clothes, trousers, skirts, Wendish shoes, and other items. She has many good customers because she goes to offices to make sales and offers credit. Sales are very good during the Christmas season.

She is requesting this loan of $750 so she can purchase more clothes to sell, and make her dream of having a large store a reality. The income from her sales help her husband with family expenses.

loans.use: Purchase clothes, shirts, trousers, pajamas, skirts to sell

loans.name: Lesly Lizeht

texts.en:
For 6 years, Lesly Lizeht C. has had a small grocery store, or pulperia as it is called in her native Honduras. She sells rice, soup, beans, soda water, and other groceries.

She is requesting this loan so she can buy more groceries to sell to more customers. She is divorced and has two children to support.

loans.use: Purchase grocery items to sell

loans.name: Maximo Nicolas

texts.en:
My names is Maximo Nicolas P.. I have a small store where I sell beans, rices, vegetables, eggs, etc. I have had this business for 5 years. Ever since I left my old job I have dedicated myself to sales. I also sell vegetables in the streets in the morning. I am very happily married to my wife. The two of us help each other a lot in order to cover the expenses of our home. We are a couple of old people that are not given work. Thank you for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein.

Mi nombre es Maximo Nicolas P., Tengo un pequeño negocio de venta de Frijoles, arroz, verduras, huevos, etc. Este negocio lo tengo hace 5 años. Desde que me corrieron de mi trabajo, me didico a la venta. Tambien vendo en las calles verduras por la mañana. Estoy casado vivo con mi esposa y los dos nos apoyamos mucho para poder cubrir gastos que tenemos en nuestro hogar, ya somos dos personas viejas que no nosdan trabajo. gracias por su ayuda

loans.use: Purchase of several products

loans.name: Fatima Jolibeth

texts.en: I am dedicated to selling clothes -- shirts, skirts, pajamas, and more -- for women and others. I have been in this business for 7 years. At times I leave to sell to offices for my better clients; they call for me because I have very good prices. My goal for next year is to have my own store. I would like this loan to help me to be able to make this a reality.

loans.use: To purchase shirts, jeans, trousers, skirts and more.

loans.name: Sandra Janeth

texts.es:
I am a traveling saleswoman and I sell in the streets and also in my home. I have 5 years of experience in sales and thank God I am doing good. My sales usually increase during the Christmas season and I already have various orders from my customers. I wouldn't like to decieve my customers. I am a single mother of 2 children and I support my family with this business.

Translated from Spanish by Yvette Diaz, Kiva volunteer.

Yo soy vendedora ambulante, yo vendo en las calles y tambien en mi casa. Tengo 5 años de dedicarme a las ventas, Gracias a Dios me ha ido bien. Ahora biene la temporada davideña las ventas se me ingrementan. Tengo varios pdidos de mis clientes y no me gustaria fallarles.Soy madre soltera de 2 hijos con este negocio mantengo a mi familia.

loans.use: Purchase of clothes for men and woman

loans.name: María Rayda

texts.es:
Maria and her husband Jesus have been craftmen ever since they were very young. Now, they have become parents of two sons and they have seen their art become a major source of income. Despite great limitations - they do not have an appropriate shop to work from - this family has not lessen their efforts and dedication. Naturally, they would like to have a better home where their children's rearing could be improved in short term. This challenge has lead to the possibility to obtain better machinery and bigger quantities of yarn that would be used to increase production output. These goods, then, would be sold in Lima and also fulfill export demand. They are aware that their dedication and hard work will eventually pay off and they will be able to purchase their home and also a place where they can work comfortably. To begin seeking their dream, they need US$500.00, that will be used to purchase additional material and tools. Let's enable this family to continue to handcraft their art and fulfill their children's dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

Maria y su esposo Jesús se han dedicado a la labor artesana desde muy pequeños y ahora que son pareja y padres de 2 niños han visto en este arte una gran fuente de ingresos económicos para su hogar. Pese a tener grandes limitaciones porque no cuentan con un taller ni una casa propia no ha disminuido la fuerza y entereza de esta familia , sin duda tienen la esperanza de poder adquirir una morada que favorezca el crecimiento de sus hijos en corto tiempo. Frente a este panorama ven la posibilidad de comprar más maquinarias y lanas que les ayudarán a agilizar su producción y comercialización semanalmente en la ciudad de Lima, además de incrementar sus pedidos de exportación. Así mismo saben que el esfuerzo que le dedican a su labor con el tiempo hará que puedan tener una casa propia y un lugar donde puedan laborar tranquilamente y para empezar a trabajar por su sueño de un futuro mejor requieren la suma de 500 dólares para adquirir materia prima y herramientas de trabajo. Hagamos que esta familia siga fabricando y anidando los sueños de sus hijos en su labor diaria.

loans.use: Purchase material and tools for a small artisan shop.

loans.name: Rosa Aminta

texts.es:
Hi, my name is Rasa Aminta L. and I sell concrete blocks. I started this business with my husband 6 years ago. I sell them at a very good price to my customers. But now I need to buy more concrete blocks because I have various orders for this month. With this business I support my family and pay for my kids education.

Translated from Spanish by Yvette Diaz, Kiva volunteer.

Hola mi nomre es Rasa Aminta L., yo me didico a la venta de bloques para construccion. Este negocio lo tengo con mi esposo hace 6 años. Yo lo vendo a un buen precio y teno mi clientela. Pero ahora necesito mas porque tengo varios pedidos para estos meses. este negocio es el que sustenta mi familia y pagos de estudios de mis hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of Cement and construction blocks

loans.name: Olga Sulema

texts.en:
Olga Sulema V. M. has been sewing and selling clothes for 3 years. She makes dresses, shirts, bed clothes to sell from her house. She increases her clientele by making uniforms. The sales from this business help her family with monthly expenses and medicine for her children.

She is asking for a loan of $200 to purchase fabric, buttons, thread, and other supplies she needs to make the clothing and uniforms.

loans.use: Purchase fabric and supplies to sew clothes

loans.name: Evelyn Patricia

texts.en:
Evelyn Patricia L. D. has been selling good quality clothes and shoes for 5 years. Her best customers are clerks, who need to dress nicely for work. The Christmas season has started, and sales will be very good during this season.

Evelyn Patricia is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase more shirts, trousers, skirts, blouses, dressing-gowns, and shoes to increase her sales. She is a single mother with 3 children, 2 of whom attend school, and she wants to increase her income to pay the school expenses.

loans.use: Purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Hilda Blanca

texts.es:
Hilda is a 43 years old lady that has always worked with handcrafted goods. Recently, after becoming aware of an international demand, she teamed up with neighbors and started to raise guinea pigs. They wanted to take part in this new opportunity to generate additional income locally. She is very pleased with this activity for it has provided substantial profits to the families involved. Business has marched along satisfactorily and, although her husband's separation and the birth of her grandchild have not come under the best circumstances, she has been able to provide for her children and grandchild. It is unknown why the father has not been providing support. Forced by a spike in household expenses, she found this interesting way to generate income. She decided to increase her investment so her daughter may also take advantage of this activity. To do so she requests an amount of US$500.00, which will be used to purchase more guinea pigs and build more cages so that they can grow in quantity. Let's participate and enable Mrs. Hilda to prosper and fulfill her family's dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

Hilda es una dama de 43 años de edad que siempre ha trabajado realizando artículos artesanales. Hace poco al enterarse de la gran oportunidad de negocio que había generado a nivel internacional la crianza de cuyes se asoció con sus vecinos para emprender este nueva oportunidad de generar ingresos adicionales dentro de su localidad.Esta actividad la tiene muy contenta porque en poco tiempo las familias que participan en esta labor han obtenido ganancias sustanciales.Las cosas han ido marchando bien y aunque la ausencia de su esposo y la llegada de su nieta al seno familiar no se han dado en las mejores circunstancias, ella ansía seguir velando por el bienestar de sus hijos y ahora también de su pequeña nieta que por diferentes motivos no recibe ningún apoyo de su progenitor. Debido a que los gastos en su hogar se han ido incrementado con el transcurrir de los días y que ha encontrado una interesante forma de generar ingresos ha decidido incrementar su capital de inversión a fin de que su hija pueda también beneficiarse con esta actividad. Por ello requiere una suma de 500 dólares con los que podrá comprar más cuyes y además acondicionar sus albergues a fin de que la cantidad se incremente rápidamente.Colaboremos para que Hilda siga albergando los sueños de su numerosa familia.

loans.use: Purchase guinea pigs and cage installation.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es:
Mrs. Alicia belongs to the "The Damsels" Communal Bank, from the A.H Luz y Paz from the Manantay District in the State of Ucayali. She is 40 years old and is mother of four children. Her husband is a construction worker. However, his income is not enough for their home expenses.

Alicia, after being invited by one of her neighbors, decided to get integrated to Manuela Ramos communal bank. With the first loan of S/ 300.00, she started selling candy, "kekes", home baked bread- since the closest bakery was 4km away. Therefore, she decided to build an artisan bakery.

With the recent loan of S/.1,200 (US $400 aprox.), granted by Manuela Ramos, which she will repay in 4 quotas, she will be able to expand and improve the oven. Purchase 1 bag of flour, 1 box of eggs, 5 kgs. of sugar, 2 boxes of milk. Therefore, she will be able to sell home baked bread, "kekes" and more.

Alicia is very happy that she can have her own oven and bake home baked bread and "kekes", allowing the neighborhood dwellers to have a closer place where to purchase and consume these products.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Alicia pertenece al Banco Comunal "Las Doncellas", del A.H. Luz y Paz del Distrito de Manantay del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 40 años, y es madre de 4 hijos, su esposo es albañil, sin embargo lo que gana no alcanza para los gastos de su hogar. Con la invitación de una vecina, Alicia decide integrar al banco comunal de Manuela Ramos y con el primer préstamo de S/ 300.00 soles decide vender golosinas, kekes, panes caseros, dado que la panificadora más cercana esta a 4 km, por lo que decide armar un horno artesanal. Con el reciente préstamo otorgado por Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,200 (US$ 400.00 aprox.) pagaderos en 4 cuotas, podrá mejorar y ampliar su horno, además comprar de 1 saco de harina, 1 caja de huevo, 5 kilos de azúcar y 2 cajas de leche, con esto podrá vender panes caseros, kekes y otros. Alicia esta muy contenta de tener su propio horno y así elaborar panes caseros, kekes permitiendo a los pobladores de ese lugar, que tengan cerca alguien que venda este producto y poder consumirlo.

loans.use: Oven maintenance and  ingredients purchase

loans.name: Maria Ingracia

texts.en:
For 10 years, Maria Ingracia S. R. has been cooking baleadas to order. Baleadas are typical food of Honduras. They are corn tortillas filled with a mixture of beans and egg, banana, and butter. She sells her popular baleadas to her neighbors and people who live nearby. She supports her 3 children with her business.

She is requesting this loan of $150 to purchase supplies to make and sell baleadas.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make baleadas to sell

loans.name: Florinda

texts.es:
Mrs Florinda belongs to a Communal Bank called " Working Women" from 341 Jr. Callao in the neighborhood of Arenal of the Calleria District in the Ucayali State. She is 60 years old and is mother of two children. Her husband, a baker, was working for a bakery that paid S/. 500.00 ( $157 US dollars), which wasn't enough to satisfy their basic house needs. Therefore, Florinda accepted her neighbor's invitation to join Manuela Ramo's Communal Bank. With the first loan of S/.300.00 soles she decided to start selling bread. Since then she had her own oven and little by little built their own artisan bread bakery.

Recently, Manuela Ramos gave them an additional loan of S/.1,500 (US $500.00 aprox.), which will be paid back in 6 quotas. She will use this loan to improve and maintain her oven and to purchase 20 bags of flour, 1 case of eggs, 3 kg. of salt, 3 kgs. of sugar and 1 bag of leavening.

Mrs Florinda is very happy to have her own business and work with her husband and sons, who attend the business. They wake up every day at 3:00 a.m. to bake the bread.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Florinda pertenece al Banco Comunal "Mujeres Trabajadoras", del Jr. Callao 341 del sector del Arenal del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 60 años y es madre D. 2 hijos, su esposo es panadero, estuvo trabajando para una panificadora donD. le pagaban S/. 500.00 (US$ 157.00), ingreso que no les era suficiente para satisfacer las necesidades básicas D. la casa. Es así que Florinda recibe la invitación D. una vecina a integrar en un Banco Comunal D. Manuela Ramos, entonces con el primer préstamo D. S/ 300.00 soles deciD. vender pan, desD. ese momento tiene la iniciativa D. tener su propio horno, por ello poco a poco construyeron su propio horno artesanal. Con el reciente préstamo otorgado por Manuela Ramos D. S/. 1,500 (US$ 500.00 aprox.) que será cancelado en 6 cuotas, mejorará su horno y dará mantenimiento al mismo, comprará 20 sacos D. harina, 1 jaba D. huevo, 3 kilos D. sal, 3 kilos D. azúcar y 1 bolsa D. levadura. La señora Florinda esta muy contenta D. tener su propio negocio y trabajar conjuntamente con su esposo y sus hijos, quienes atienden el negocio, se levantan a las 3.00 am para elaborar el pan..

loans.use: to maintain the bakery's oven and purchase ingredients

loans.name: Maria Antonia

texts.en:
Maria Antonia A. L. has been selling cosmetics for 6 years. During the day, she sells creams, shampoo, and lotions in the streets in San Lorenzo, where she lives. In the evening, she sells the cosmetics in the business market opposite her house.

She is requesting a loan of $150 to purchase more cosmetics to sell during the Christmas season. She uses the profit form her sales to purchase her medicine.

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Iris Isabel

texts.es:
Sra. Iris belongs to the "Mujeres Trabajadoras" (Working Women) community bank in Ucayali, a region or "departamento" of Peru. She is 38 years old and the mother of 3 children; her partner is out of work and, due to his age, will find it difficult to get work in the future.

Iris has taken on responsibility for her household's expenses. She learned about Mujeres Trabajadoras from her sister. With her first loan of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$94), she started a business selling shellfish, something especially popular with foreigners.

With a recently-granted loan of S/.1,300 (approximately US433), to be repaid over 6 months, she will buy wholesale supplies of shellfish at a discounted price. She will also buy crabs, clams, 5 kilograms of "yuyo" (a local seaweed used in cooking), 10 kilograms of octopus, and blocks of ice to keep it all fresh.

Together, she and her partner operate this business, rising at 4am, she to sell the shellfish and he and her children to make breakfast, each one with their separate responsibilities. She is very happy to have the chance to operate this business and be able to cover the needs of the household.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Iris pertenece al Banco Comunal "Mujeres Trabajadoras", del Jr. Calvo de Araujo 1198 sector del Arenal del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 38 años de edad y es madre de 3 hijos, su pareja no tiene trabajo, le es difícil de conseguir debido a su edad.

Iris asume todos los gastos de la casa, es así que por invitación de su hermana se integra al Banco Comunal "Mujeres Trabajadoras". Con el primer préstamo recibido de S/. 300 (US$ 94.00 aprox.) decide vender mariscos dado que en la ciudad hay mucha gente foránea, y les gusta los mariscos.

Con el reciente préstamo otorgado por Manuela R. de S/. 1,300 (US$ 433.00 aprox.) pagadero en 6 cuotas, comprará mariscos al por mayor y así obtener un mejor precio. También comprará 1 saco de cangrejos, 5 kilos de yuyo, 1 saco de choros, 10 kilos de pulpo, 5 barras de hielo para mantener fresco los mariscos.

Ahora conjuntamente con su pareja atienden este negocio, se levantan a las 4.00 am., ella para ir a vender los Mariscos, su pareja e hijos para hacer el desayuno, cada uno ya tienen sus obligaciones. Ella esta muy contenta de tener la oportunidad del negocio y poder cubrir las necesidades de la casa.

loans.use: Buy wholesale supplies of shellfish.

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es:
Sra. Lidia belongs to the "Las Doncellas" (The Damsels) community bank in Ucayali, a region or "departamento" of Peru. She is 38 years old and the mother of 4 children. Her husband is a cab driver and earns very little so Lidia decided to set up a business at home, making lingerie and other clothing. With her first loan of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$94) from Manuela Ramos, she started a business making clothing for women, selling what she made door-to-door.

The recently-granted loan of S/.500 (approximately US$167) from Manuela Ramos, which will be repaid in 4 installments, will be used to maintain her sewing machine and to buy 8 kilograms of cotton material, 1 dozen spools of thread and other materials.

Lidia feels complete because dressmaking is what she likes doing above all and it's given her the opportunity to earn income for the family's expenses and to provide for her young chidren.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Lidia pertenece al Banco Comunal "Las Doncellas", del A. H. Primavera 2da etapa Mz 22 Lt 16 del Distrito de Manantay del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 38 años de edad y es madre de 4 niños, su esposo es taxista, dado que su ingreso es mínimo, Lidia decide poner un negocio en su casa, se dedica a la confección de ropa y lencería. Con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 soles decide confeccionar ropa para mujeres y la mercadería la venda casa por casa dando facilidades de pago.

El reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 500 (US$ 167.00 aprox.) que cancelará en 4 cuotas, será utilizado para dar mantenimiento a su máquina y comprar 8 kilos de telas de algodón, 1 docena de conos de hilos y 3 conos de elástico.

Lidia se siente realizada dado que la costura es lo que más le gusta y con ello tiene la oportunidad de generar ingresos para los gastos de la familia, además de cuidar de sus pequeños hijos.

loans.use: Maintenance for sewing machine and purchases of cloth, threads, etc. for women's clothing business.

loans.name: Rosita Misksy

texts.es:
Srta. Rosita belongs to "Las Doncellas" (The Damsels) community bank in Ucayali, a region or "departamento" of Peru. She is 29 years old and the mother of 2 small children. Her partner is a security guard at a retail store but his salary doesn't cover all of the household expenses so Rosita began looking for ideas for businesses that she could start at home where she cares for her two young children. With her first loan of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or approximately US$94) from Manuela Ramos, she decided to set up a small home-based grocery business, the only one in a 6-block area.

With a recently-granted loan of S/.700 (approximately US$233) from Manuela Ramos, to be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy a range of products for the business, e.g., charcoal, platanos, salt, rice, sugar and soft drinks.

In order to make time for other household chores, Rosita gets up at 4am every morning so that she can bring the merchandise she needs from a market that is 8 kilometers (5 miles) away. She's very pleased that she can operate the business in her own house, something that also allows her to take care of her family at home.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosita pertenece al Banco Comunal "Las Doncellas", del A.H. Primavera 2da. Etapa MZ 30 Lt. 15 del Distrito de Manantay del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 29 años de edad y es madre de 2 pequeños hijos, su pareja es vigilante de una tienda comercial, su sueldo no alcanza para cubrir las necesidades de la casa, por ello Rosita buscó emprender algún negocio dado que también tiene que atender a sus hijos, fue entonces que, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 soles decidió poner una bodega en su casa, dado que la más cercana esta a 6 cuadras.

Con el reciente préstamo otorgado por Manuela Ramos de S/. 700.00 (US$ 233 aprox.) pagadero en 4 cuotas, comprará variados productos como 1 saco de carbón, 1 racimo de plátano verde, media bolsa de sal, 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar y 3 cajas de gaseosas.

Rosita, para no descuidar los quehaceres de la casa, se levanta a las 4:00 de la mañana y trae productos en cantidad del mercado mas cercano que esta a 8 km del lugar. Se siente muy contenta de tener el negocio en su misma casa, ya que le permite, también, atender los quehaceres de la casa.

loans.use: Buy grocery products for resell.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
This woman is from the city of León. She started her business at the edge of the León central market 20 years ago with modest capital of barely C$1,500 córdobas ($80), contributed by her husband who is a soldier in the Nicaraguan army.

When she realized that her husband's salary would not cover their and their children's needs, she decided to start said business, which at the beginning only consisted of a few items of cheap clothing in a makeshift stall made out of plastic, wood and cardboard. With much work and sacrifice she was able to build her humble home and pay to educate her children, one of which is still young and in primary school. Now she runs her business in a small space located in a new part of the central market. She has one employee that helps with sales. She now offers a large variety of products: Clothing, shoes, cosmetics, picture frames, articles for children etc. Her business, however, is still on a small scale.The first loan that CEPRODEL granted her was for C$1,500 córdobas and has helped her for three years (even though she still sold her products in the streets).

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

Esta señora es originaria de la ciudad de León. Su negocio empieza en las afueras del mercado central de León hace más de 20 años con un modesto capital de trabajo de apenas C$ 1,500 córdobas (U$$ 80 dólares), aportados por su esposo el cual labora como soldado del ejército de Nicaragua.

Ella al observar que el sueldo de su esposo no lograba cubrir las necesidades propias y de sus hijos, decide iniciar dicho negocio, el cual al principio contaba con algunas piezas de ropa barata, en una pequeña caseta improvisada, con plásticos, madera y cartón. Como fruto de su esfuerzo y perseverancia con mucho sacrificio logró construir su humilde vivienda y darles educación a sus dos hijos. Uno de ellos aún está pequeño y cursa su educación primaria. Actualmente, el negocio tiene un pequeño local ubicado dentro de nuevas áreas del mercado central, tiene una trabajadora la cual le ayuda con su venta. Ella ahora oferta una amplia variedad de productos: Ropa, Zapatos, cosméticos, marcos para retratos, artículos para niños, etc. Aunque siempre menor escala. El primer crédito que le otorgó CEPRODEL, fue de C$ 1,500 córdobas con quien tiene más de 3 años de trabajar (desde que aún vendía en la calle).

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Maria Del  Socorro

texts.es:
This woman is of an advanced age (68 years old) and is from the country. She started her business over 20 years ago in the central market of León with the meager sum of 200 dollars. She had saved that money from many years of work as a domestic worker, which was her job until she started her business. She started her small business in the central market of León selling jewelry. Her stall was made of wood, plastic and cardboard that had been thrown away.

Through much effort she successfully raised her three children, that all work and can help her very little because they now have their families and do not earn very much. She now takes care of two grandchildren, whose father works in Costa Rica. Her grandchildren help her out in the business and at home. There is no doubt that Mrs. Socorro is a hard worker. She has worked with CEPRODEL for over two years and has a very good loan record. Her strore is now located in a new part of the central market and she now offers a wide variety of products: Clothing, shoes, belts, etc. Her business is still a modest one because she deals in small quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

Esta señora es una señora mayor (68 años de edad) originaria del campo. Su negocio empieza hace más de 20 años en las aceras del mercado central de León, con la pequeña suma de US$ 200 dólares, producto de su ahorro de varios años de esfuerzo laborando como empleada doméstica, actividad que desempeñaba antes de tener su negocio. El pequeño negocio inicia en la acera del mercado central de León, con la oferta de bisutería, el tramito estaba hecho con desperdicios de madera, plástico y cartón.

Por medio de su esfuerzo logra criar a sus tres hijos los cuales trabajan y le ayudan muy poco ya que estos tienen su propia familia y ganan muy poco. Además, ella actualmente tiene a su cargo a dos nietos de un hijo que trabaja en Costa Rica, los cuales la acompañan en el negocio y en su casa. No hay duda que doña Socorro es una luchadora. Ella tiene más de dos años de trabajar con CEPRODEL, con muy buen record crediticio. El negocio ahora está ubicado en una nueva área del mercado central de León, oferta una gran variedad de productos: Ropa, Zapatos, fajas, etc. Aunque en pequeñas cantidades, pues su negocio es aún modesto.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Flor De Maria

texts.es:
This business is located in the León central market and is a humble, makeshift, mobile post made from plastic, wood and cardboard. When Flor de maría started her business she sold cigarettes and sweets out of a basket. Later on, she started to sell other products like soft drinks (with a small iced thermos), juices and jewelry. She has had her business for over 9 years. She continues to work hard to give her four children a good education. Three of her children are in secondary school and one is in primary school.

Thanks to her hard work she has been able to buy her own home. Her husband works as a driver and helps cover household expenses. She has been an excellent borrower at CEPRODEL for over 3 years. We hope that, just like other borrowers who started selling in the streets, she will one day have her own store in better conditions since she works under the hot sun of the city of León, one of the cities in Nicaragua with the highest temperature (around 37 degrees Celsius or approximately 99 degrees Fahrenheit.). She is another good example of valor, hard work and sacrifice.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

Este negocio está ubicado en las aceras del mercado Central de León, es un humilde puesto móvil elaborado con plástico, madera y cartón de forma improvisada. El negocio inicia más humilde todavía, con un pequeño canasto vendiendo cigarrillos y golosinas, más tarde ella fue incluyendo la venta de otros productos tales como: gaseosas (con un pequeño termo con hielo), jugos y bisutería. El negocio tiene más de 9 años de existir. Ella continúa esforzándose por dar educación a sus hijos los cuales son cuatro, tres de ellos cursan su educación secundaria y uno cursa su primaria.

El esfuerzo realizado le ha permitido tener su propia vivienda. Su esposo trabaja como conductor y es quien le apoya con los gastos del hogar. Ha sido un excelente cliente de CEPRODEL, por más de 3 años. Esperamos que al igual que otros clientes que empezaron vendiendo en la calle, ella pueda tener su propio módulo en mejores condiciones, ya que ella trabaja bajo el inclemente sol de la ciudad de León, una de las ciudades de Nicaragua con las más altas temperaturas (alrededor de los 37 grados centígrados). Otro ejemplo de valor, trabajo y sacrificio.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Tania

texts.es:
Tania has a small stall and sells groceries and other household products in the central market of León. She has had this business for over 20 years. In fact, Mrs. V. has been selling products in the market all of her life. Her mother had a small stall in the same market and Tania helped her until she got married. Her husband passed away and now Tania has to cover 100% of her family's needs because she still has three single and young children. She obtained part of the capital to start her business through savings and the other portion was through loans. She also got a small amount of merchandise from her mother, who closed down her own business.

Through her hard work, she was able to put her three children through professional school. Her son is an electrical engineer, one of her daughters has a degree in business administration and her other daughter has a degree in Turism and hospitality. Tania has been working with CEPRODEL for over three years and has an excellent loan record.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio es un pequeño puesto de venta de abarrotes y otros productos del hogar ubicado en el mercado central de León, el cual tiene más de 20 años de existir. De hecho la señora V. se ha dedicado toda la vida a vender en el mercado. Su madre poseía un pequeño puesto en el mismo mercado y ella le asistía hasta el momento en el que se casó. Sin embargo, su marido fallece y ella tiene la necesidad de asumir el 100% de la carga del hogar ya que aún tenía hijos solteros y jóvenes. Parte del capital para iniciar el negocio lo obtuvo de unos pequeños ahorros y otro a través de préstamos, además, para aquel entonces su mamá ya iba abandonando el negocio y ella le dejo una pequeña cantidad de mercadería.

Por medio de su esfuerzo, ella logró dar educación profesional a sus tres hijos teniendo un Ing. Electrónico, una hija Lic. En administración de empresas y una Lic. En Administración Turística y Hotelera. Tiene más de tres años de trabajar con CEPRODEL y posee un excelente record crediticio.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Nohemi De Los Angele

texts.es:
Nohemi has had her business for over thirty years. She started it when she was very young and counted on the support of her husband who, in the 1980s, worked for ENABAS, a state agency in charge of gathering and distributing basic grains.

Her business started aa a humble one, with a few bags of products, because her start-up capital was limited. Then her husband stopped working for ENABAS and started to work in the store with her to inrease sales and supplies. Through their hard work, they were able to start another grocery stand near their first one in order to make up for low sales due to the economic crisis that was affecting their country. Thanks to her hard work, Mrs. O. is now able to put their three children through professional school.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

Esta señora tiene más de 30 años de tener su negocio, ella inicia desde muy joven y contó con el apoyo de su esposo quien en los años 80´s trabajaba para ENABAS, órgano del estado que se encargaba del acopio y distribución de la producción de granos básicos.

El negocio empieza de forma humilde, con unos cuantos sacos de algunos productos, debido al capital inicial reducido. Luego su esposo deja de laborar allí y se integra al negocio para apoyarle en la venta y abastecimiento de Mercadería. Producto del esfuerzo de ambos señores, ellos logran poner otro pequeño puesto de abarrotes junto al puesto inicial como una forma de compensar las bajas ventas producto de la crisis económica que sufre la población del país. Gracias a su esfuerzo, la señora O. está formando profesionalmente a sus tres hijos.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Francisca Geronima

texts.es:
Francisca has a small food stand in the Leon market. She started out 15 years ago selling soda and juice out of a cooler and has worked hard to get to the point where she is now. With the help of her children, she started a small business cooking and serving food at the market. The business started simply--she had only one small table and six plastic chairs and she cooked the food at home and brought it in. With the help of the whole family, the business has grown since then, thanks in part also to her three-year relationship with CEPRODEL. This business has allowed Francisca to prepare her children to succeed.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Esta señora posee un pequeño comedor ubicado en el mercado de la terminal de León. Esta señora ha luchado fuertemente por hacer crecer su negocio. Ella empieza desde hace más de 15 años con un pequeño capital de US$ 150 dólares vendiendo gaseosas, jugos y otras bebidas con un termo con hielo. Sin embargo, con la ayuda de sus hijos, empieza a preparar comida, la cual era elaborada en su casa y vendida en el local que actualmente posee (claro que las condiciones del mismo era muy diferente al actual), solamente tenía una mesa y seis sillas plásticas.

Poco a poco la actividad fue rindiendo frutos, por medio de los créditos otorgados por CEPRODEL, con quien tiene más de 3 años de trabajar y al esfuerzo conjunto de su familia ella ha logrado realizar otras mejoras a su negocio. Gracias al esfuerzo realizado ella ha logrado preparar profesionalmente a sus 4 hijos.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a small food stall.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma has a small general store at the market in Leon. She started out more than twenty years ago selling candy and cigarettes in front of the bus terminal. After several years of hard work, she obtained a small loan from Banco Popular and set up a small stand selling watches and cosmetics. She started selling some clothing from her makeshift hut of wood, cardboard and plastic. She added cheap toys to the mix and continued to grow the business. Norma is the single mother of two--one in grade school and the other in high school. Thanks to many years of effort she has seen her children advance and provided a humble home for them.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Esta señora posee un pequeño, pero bien surtido negocio de mercadería en general ubicado en el mercado de la terminal de León. Ella inicia hace más de 20 años con un pequeño canasto de venta de cigarrillos y golosinas, ubicada frente a la parada de buses, ella trabajaba en la acera de la terminal.

Luego de varios años de esfuerzo, logra mediante un pequeño crédito del Banco Popular poner una pequeña mesa de relojes y cosméticos, luego vino la venta de algunas piezas de ropa, para ese entonces ya contaba con una pequeña caseta hecha de madera, cartón y plástico, más tarde agregó venta de juguetes baratos y en fin poco a poco fue surtiendo su negocio. Ella es madre soltera con un total de 2 hijos los cuales están estudiando uno en primaria y otro en secundaria. Gracias al esfuerzo de muchos años ha logrado sacar adelante a sus hijos y obtener su humilde casa.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for a general store.

loans.name: Felipa Del Socorro

texts.es:
Felipa has a small general store at the Leon market. She has been in business for 22 years. The early days were quite difficult. She started out selling candy and cigarettes. Later, she got a loan from Banco Popular and expanded into cosmetics, then added cheap shoes, clothing and jewelry. Felipa was widowed nine years ago and since then she has cared for her children alone. She has four children. One still lives with her, two others have set up their own businesses in Leon and the fourth has lived in Costa Rica for two years. As you can see, Felipa has had a difficult life.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Esta señora es propietaria de un pequeño negocio de mercadería en general ubicado en el mercado de la terminal de León. El negocio tiene más de 22 años de existencia, aunque en condiciones mucho más precarias. El negocio se origina a partir de la venta de cigarrillos y golosinas, más tarde la señora M. introduce la línea de algunos cosméticos mediante un crédito obtenido del extinto Banco Popular, agregando luego otros productos como ropa, zapatos baratos, bisutería en general, etc.

La señora M. es viuda desde hace más de 9 años y desde que falleció su esposo ella ha asumido el 100% de los gastos del hogar. De sus cuatro hijos actualmente uno vive con ella, dos pusieron su pequeño negocio en otros mercados de León y una vive en Costa Rica desde hace dos años. Como puede observarse la lucha de esta señora ha sido dura.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for a general store.

loans.name: Ni Putu Okayani

texts.id:
Like most people living in a village, Okayoni and family lives from farming. They rent / contract a 50 are (5000 square meters) land for Rp1,000,000 (about US$110)/year. Usually they planted all sorts of plants with short harvest, yet provide enough profit, like assortment of vegetables, as has been done in the last 6 months. With a loan for Rp3,500,000 (about US$385) Okayoni and husband I Ketut Sudi Utama plant long beans. This vegetable is selected by Okayoni to conform with current season, and the cost are not too high, and easy maintenance. Okayoni spends Rp2,850,000 (about $315) including payment to 3 women helpers trained to pick up the harvest after 45-65 days. Picking the beans were done once every 2 days, and each worker was paid Rp20,000 (about $2.20)/day. Expected sales in one harvest 3 month period (from planting till finish harvesting) was Rp4,800,000 (about US$530), so the profit within that 3 months was Rp1,950,000 (about $215). This helps Okayoni's family economy to pay for their 3 children's education expenses, who are all still in Grade school.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Sebagaimana umumnya orang yang hidup di desa, Okayoni dan keluarganya hidup dari hasil mengolah tanah pertanian . Tanah 50 are milik orang lain yang Okayoni sewa / kontrak selama setahun sebesar Rp 1.000.000,- Biasanya di tanami berbagai jenis tanaman yang masa panenya cepat namun dapat menghasilkan keuntungan yang lumayan misalnya jenis tanaman sayur –sayuran .Seperti apa yang di lakukannya sejak 6 bulan terakhir ini, Dengan modal yang di pinjam dari Dinari sebesar Rp 3.500.000,-Okayoni yang di bantu oleh I Ketut Sudi Utama, suaminya, menekuni menanam sayuran jenis kacang panjang. Sayuran ini di pilih Okayoni di sesuaikan dengan musim yang terjadi saat ini , juga karena biaya yang di perlukan tidak terlalu banyak dan perawatanya pun mudah. Dari sekitar 35 are tanah yang telah ditanami kacang panjang , Okayoni menghabiskan biaya sebesar Rp 2 .850.000,- biaya itu telah termasuk ongkos 3 orang pekerja wanita yang di ajak memetik hasil panen pada masa panen raya saat tanaman berumur 45 sampai dengan 65 hari. Pemetikan dilakukan setap 2 hari sekali . dan masing masing pekerja di bayar Rp 20.000, -/ harinya . Hasil penjualan yang di dapat Okayoni dalam satu periode masa panen yaitu 3 Bulan , ( dari mulai tanam sampai selesai panen ) sebesar Rp 4.800.000,- jadi keuntungan yang di dapat Okayoni dalam 3 Bulan sebesar Rp 1 .950.000,- . Hasil ini sangat membantu perekonomian keluarga Okayoni lebih- lebih dalam memenuhi biaya kebutuhan pendidikan 3 orang anaknya yang semua masih duduk di bangku sekolah dasar.

loans.use:
To buy long bean seeds, fertlizer and medicine

Membeli bibit kacang panjang, pupuk dan obat - obatan

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sunadi

texts.id:
In Bali, wife's role in the family is very important. Besides raising children, also manage household needs, awife is also required to have enough income to support husband's income, so that all needs could be fulfilled. Thi role is fulfilled by Ni Ketut Sunadi since she married I Wayan Suda, a man who works as a tenant farmer. Mature age is not stopping Sunadi to do business. For Sunadi raising pigs does not require a lot of energy. Important is capital and persistant for her to expand the business. Her last sales was Rp1,950,000 (about US$220) from sales of 2 pigs, that she raised for 5 months with a capital of Rp750,000 (about $82.50) for feed expense, and Rp400,000 (about $44) for feedstock. Sunadi's profit was Rp800,000 (about $88). Sunadi plans to expand her business by obtaining a loan from Dinari for Rp1,500,000 (about $165), which will be used to buy 4 piglets, since 2 parts of her stall are now empty, because the pigs were sold to pay for Final exams expenses of her child I Putu Pande Kartika Yasa, who finished Mechanical Middle School. Sunadi hopes the results to be obtained would better than previously, so that it could pay for her child's higher education, which up to now is still postponed.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Di Bali peranan Istri dalam suatu rumah tangga sangatlah penting. Disamping sebagai pengasuh anak-anak dan juga mengurus segala keperluan rumah tangga seorang istri juga dituntut untuk dapat memiliki penghasilan yang mampu menunjang pendapatan suami sehingga semua kebutuhan bisa terpenuhi. Peranan ini telah di lakukan oleh Ni Ketut sunadi sejak menikah dengan I Wayan Suda, laki-laki yang kesehariannya bekerja sebagai petani . Usia yang kini semakin lanjut tak menghalangi Sunadi untuk terus berusaha , bagi Sunadi memelihara ternak babi tidak memerlukan tenaga terlalu banyak , yang penting ada modal dan ketekunan itu sudah cukup baginya untuk mengembangkan usaha ini. Hasil penjualan terakhir yang di peroleh Sunadi sebesar Rp 1.950.000,- dari 2 Ekor ternak yang di pelihara selama 5 bulan .dengan menghabiskan modal sebesar Rp 750.000,- untuk biaya pakan dan Rp 400.000,- Untuk Bibitnya, Sunadi mendapat keuntungan sebesar Rp 800.000 ,- Sunadi bermaksud mengembangkan usahanya ini dengan meminjam modal dari Dinari, sebesar Rp 1.500.000 ,- yang di pergunakan untuk membeli 4 ekor bibit lagi, karena dua bagian kandang miliknya kini kosong karena babinya di jual untuk biaya Ujian Akhir anaknya, I Putu Pande Kartika Yasa,yang telah menyelesaikan sekolah mekanik (STM). Dan Sunadi pun Berharap hasil yang di dapatnya lebih baik dari sebelumnya. Sehingga bisa membiayai kelanjutan pendidikan anaknya ke Perguruan Tinggi yang sampai sat ini masih tertunda.

loans.use:
To buy pig feedstock

Membeli bibit babi

loans.name: Taumainuumau

texts.en: Taumainuumau is an old lady who supports her family by running her vegetable garden. She is 60 years old and has 6 kids. She attends the market to sell her produce once a week, and she can make $200-300 per visit. She uses the money to support her family and to pay school fees for her grandchildren.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her garden

loans.name: Ni Putu Widiantari

texts.id:
To have a constant income that could help her husband's salary is the reason that Ni Putu Widiantari to be a pig farmer, a mother blessed with a baby since last year. Although a business considered young, her income is not bad. From sales of 2 piglets bought for Rp150,000 (about US$16.50)/piece, after 3 months sold for Rp450,000 (about $49.50)/piece. While feeding expense was only Rp250,000 (about $27.50). This gave Widiantari motivation to increase her farmed animals. Dinari additional capital of Rp1,500,000 (about $165) will be used to build a stall with cement floor and bamboo walls. A very simple stall, but enough to provide comfort to her animals. The rest would be used to buy feedstock. Widiantari is proud of what she has done so far, because with it, Widiantari could have an income, and help her husband's burden who received just enough salary as a carpenter. While rearing up her 2 year old child, Widiantari did not forget her responsibilty as a housewife, and mother's activities in her village.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Memiliki sumber pendapatan tetap yang mampu membantu penghasilan suami menjadi alasan Ni Putu Widiantari untuk menekuni memelihara babi . Ibu rumah tangga yang baru di karuniai seorang anak ini mulai menekuni memelihara babi sejak 1 tahun yang lalu. Meski tergolong usaha yang masih muda, hasil yang di perolehnya cukup lumayan. Dari hasil penjualan 2 ekor ternak babi yang di belinya dengan harga 150.000,- / ekor, setelah tiga bulan laku di jual Rp 450.000,-/ ekor. Sedangkan biaya pakan yang di habiskan hanya Rp 250.000, -. Hasil itu memacu semangat Widiantari untuk menambah ternak peliharaanya Dinari memberikan tambahan modal kepada Widiantari sebesar Rp 1.500.000,-yang dipergunakan untuk membuat kandang dengan alas semen dan dinding bambu. Suatu kandang yang sangat sederhana tetapi mampu memberi rasa nyaman bagi ternak-ternak peliharaannya. Kemudian sisa uangnya di belikan bibit . Widiantari sangat bangga dengan apa yang dapat dikerjakannya saat ini , karena dengan begitu ,Widiantari bisa mempunyai penghasilan dan bisa meringankan beban suaminya yang punya penghasilan pas-pasan sebagai tukang kayu. Sambil mengasuh I Gusti Putu Desta Winata, anaknya yang masih balita ( 2 Th ), Widiantari juga tak melupakan tanggung jawabnya sebagai ibu rumah tangga dan selalu aktif dalam kegiatan ibu –ibu PKK di desanya.

loans.use:
To built better stall and buy pig feedstock

Membuat kandang yg lebih baik dan membeli bibit babi

loans.name: Masina

texts.en: Masina K. is a 62-year-old married mother of 6 kids. Two of her children have moved overseas, but the rest are still in Samoa. Masina used to rely on regular remittances from her overseas children until she joined the program last year. Since then, she has started a taro plantation and started making her own money by selling taro at the market and to fellow villagers.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Faletaulupe

texts.en: Living in a rural area is not so simple for the townswomen. Faletaulupe, who comes from the town of Vaivase, gets along nicely. She is married to a farmer from Saleaumua and is raising four children. Her husband runs a taro plantation along with 3 laborers. She goes to the market twice a month, and she can make $150-$200 every week. She is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, weed killer, and other supplies for the taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gramoxone (a weed killer), and other supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Eni

texts.en: Eni is a married mother of four children from the village of Matautu Falealili. Her business is a vegetable garden. Her husband and two sons work on the garden. Her last loan of $300 was used to buy supplies for her vegetable garden. She is applying for this loan in order to keep her children in school and to support her family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, gramoxone (a weed killer), and other supplies for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Lopeta

texts.en: Lopeta is married to a farmer from the village of Salepouae and runs a taro plantation. She sells her products in front of her house. Twice a week she sells at the market as well. She makes $250-$300 per week, which she uses to support her family and to pay school fees for her kids.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Lupe

texts.en: Lupe is a 48-year-old mother of two. Her business is running a flea market stall. She sells handicrafts in front of her house and at a stall at the Savalalo market. She makes $100-150 a day from selling handicrafts, and she uses her earnings to help support her family.

loans.use: To buy supplies and inventory for her flea market stall

loans.name: Laumata

texts.en: Laumata is a married mother of 7 from the village of Alaoa. She operates a sewing business, and she has recently joined SPBD’s loan program in order to receive financial assistance for her business. She spends most of her time in her sewing room, and she hopes that she can make more money in order to support her family and to help out with the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Bambang Hermanto

texts.id:
Bambang Hermanto, 56 years old, born in Jember, East Java, and lives in Gilimanuk, West Bali. Bambang already lives in Bali since graduated from Mechanical Middle School in Java. He is doing it, because he has the aspiration to better his life, although he has to move to another place far from home. To channel his expertise, Bambang opened a motorcycle workshop. He is doing this business until now where he has grandchildren. Bambang lives in a simple house with his wife, because his children are married, and live with their own families. Because of his long expertise in automotive business, Bambang's workshop is always busy serving customers. Bambang got help from his son in law, who is also a mechanic. With loan from Dinari, Bambang plans to buy various spare parts to upgrade his facilities. This is to provide best service for customers, and so would bring more customers, and would directly impact on his income.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Bambang Hermanto, 56 tahun, asli kelahiran Jember , Jawa Timur dan tinggal di Gilimanuk - Bali barat. Bambang sudah tinggal di Bali sejak tamat sekolah mekanik ( STM ) di Jawa. Hal itu dilakukannya, karena ia mempunyai semangat untuk meningkatkan kesejahteraan hidupnya walaupun hal itu harus ditempuhnya dengan harus merantau jauh dari rumah. Untuk menyalurkan keahliannya, Bambang membuka usaha bengkel sepeda motor. Usaha itu dilakukannya hingga sekarang ia sudah mempunyai cucu. Bambang tinggal di rumahnya yang sederhana bersama dengan istrinya, karena anaknya sudah menikah dan tinggal bersama keluarganya masing – masing. Karena sudah mempunyai pengalaman yang cukup lama di bidang otomotif, bengkel Bambang selalu ramai dikunjungi pelanggan. Untuk dapat melayani pelanggan dengan baik, Bambang dibantu oleh menantunya yang juga seorang mekanik. Dengan pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari, Bambang berencana untuk membeli aneka jenis spare part motor dan olie untuk melengkapi fasilitasnya. Hal itu dimaksudkan untuk memberi pelayanan yang terbaik bagi pelanggan dan dengan itu akan mendatangkan lebih banyak lagi pelanggan yang secara langsung akan meningkatkan pendapatannya.

loans.use:
To buy spare parts, and assortment of oils to upgrade his facilities

Membeli spare part dan aneka jenis olie untuk melengkapi fasilitasnya

loans.name: Tufaina

texts.en: Tufaina is a new member of SPBD. She is 25 years old and recently quit her job because she wanted to work from home, where she can look after her two children. She makes more than $100 a week by selling pancakes, and she uses the money to support her family and kids.

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar, and oil for her pancake business

loans.name: Pala

texts.en: Pala is a 24-year-old single woman who is trying to support her family. She recently joined SPBD’s loan program in order to receive financial assistance for her family’s banana plantation. She plans to buy supplies in order to improve her business and make it sustainable.

loans.use: To buy gramoxone (a weed killing chemical), spades, and other supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Pine

texts.en: Although she left school at a young age, Pine has gotten by using her talent sewing clothes in a variety of prints and colors. She joined SPBD’s loan program in order to continue her business to help support her family.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies for her business

loans.name: Turimin

texts.id:
Turimin, although already 67 year old, his enthusiasm toward being productive did not decline. Life’s demand had endured him through 25 years of this lime stone effort. With Rp 2.000.000 (about USD 222) – Turimin can purchase I truck load of limestone and firewood for burning the limestone to produce lime. This is performed once a week. The end result being lime powder is sold for Rp 2.400.000 (USD 266), to shrimp farmers to balance the acidity of the water. Thus generating a profit of Rp 400.000 (USD45) to support his family (wife and 6 children) until they are independent. At the moment Turimin living with his wife while his married children have jobs of their own. Thus he and his wife can concentrate on this effort to provide for their retirement and improve their current simple and basic home he owns. With this loan from DINARI plan to grow his effort by purchasing more raw materials thus increasing his profit.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Turimin sudah mencapai usia 67 tahun, tapi semangatnya untuk tetap produktif tidak pernah surut. Tuntutan hidup membuatnya bertahan dalam menjalankan usahanya mengolah batu kapur selama 25 th. Dengan modal Rp 2.000.000,- Turimin membeli 1 truk batu kapur dan kayu bakar yang dipakai mengolah batu kapur tersebut. Hal ini dilakukannya 1 minggu sekali sesuai dengan waktu yang diperlukan dlm mengolah batu kapur tersebut. Hasil olahan batu kapur yang sudah berupa bubuk dijualnya kepada pengusaha tambak udang untuk dipakai mengatur keasaman air dengan harga Rp.2.400.000,- Sehingga Turimin mendapat keuntungan Rp. 400.000 . Dari hasil usahanya inilah Turimin menanggung biaya hidup istri dan enam orang anaknya sehingga mereka bisa mandiri dengan memiliki usaha sendiri. Saat ini Turimin tinggal berdua dengan istri sedangkan anak-anaknya sudah menikah dan memiliki usaha masing-masing.Dengan demikian Turimin lebih berkonsentrasi dalam pekerjaannya bersama istri untuk kehidupan di masa tuanya dan mengadakan perbaikan atas rumah sederhana yang ditempainya saat ini. Dengan mendapat pinjaman dari DINARI Turimin berencana mengembang usahanya dengan membeli bahan baku yang lebih banyak sehingga hasilnyapun bisa meningkat.

loans.use: Purchase lime stone (Membeli batu kapur)

loans.name: Zulfughar

texts.ru:
Zulfughar lives with his parents in Saatli, Azerbaijan. Two years ago, after finishing college, he could not find a job because of the high unemployment rate. In order to support his elderly parents, he rented a café in Saatli and started his business.

The work was going well and he even hired an employee. Business started increasing and Zulfughar started thinking about replacing some equipment. He purchased tables and chairs and now plans on purchasing a dishwashing machine. The dishwasher costs around $500 and Zulfughar turned to Normicro, a KIVA partner, with a loan request.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Мр. Зулфугар живет в месте со своими родителями в городе Саатлы Республики Азербайджан, расположенной в Закавказье. Два года назад, после окончания института, он не мог найти себе работу из-за высокого уровня безработицы и, чтобы содержать своих престарелых родителей, он арендовал кафе в городе Саатлы и начал своё дело. Работа пошла неплохо, и даже он нанял работника. Бизнес начал подниматься и Зулфугар начал подумывать о замене недоторого оборудования. Он уже закупил столы и стулья и теперь планирует о покупке посудомоечной машины. Стоит она около 500 долларов и поэтому Зулфугар обратился к микрокредитной организации "Нормикро" - партнеру КИВА - с просьбой о предоставлении ему кредита.

loans.use: To purchase a dishwasher

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Born in 1962, Regina is married and is a mother of six children, two of which are below 15 years of age.  As a caring wife and mother, she has always worked hard to support her husband and educate their children.  Motivated by other members, she decided to join GHAPE so she could obtain a business loan.

With a loan of $100, she plans to invest in the cultivation of yams, vegetables and corn which are all highly consumed food stuffs in the area.  She plans to sell these crops and raise money to support her husband in paying school fees for their children and to feed the family.

She plans to repay the loan in 12 months with the first installment on the day the loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of corn seeds and yam setts

loans.name: Elghun

texts.en:
Mr. Elghun is a low income vulnerable person. He is 24 and lives in the village of Saatli city, which is situated in the south-central area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.

Elghun rents a small shop in the local bazaar of Saatli town and sells food. The business is very successful and needs some investment to increase the daily sales, but Elghun has no collateral to apply to the commercial banks.

That's why he applied to Normicro Saatli branch for a $700 loan. This credit could let him buy and sell more goods and better provide the necessities of life for his parents.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Ilkham

texts.en:
Mr. Ilham is a 32-year-old man. He is a farmer. He lives with his family in the village of Saatli city which is situated in the central part of Azerbaijan.

He started his business in 2002, when he purchased one cow with money he had saved up. Since then, Ilham has collected up to seven cattle. He buys calves, breeds them, cuts and sells to the butcher, who works in the local market.

Ilham has collected enough customers and needs more animals in his herd. This project requires investment. For this purpose, Ilham applied for a $700 loan from Normicro to buy five calves. He hopes eventually to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Mushvig

texts.ru:
Mushvig lives in a suburb of Saatli, Azerbaijan, located in the Southern Caucasus. He is married and is 28 years old. 10 years ago he started his business by renting a store in Saatli. Using his personal savings he filled it with goods. He purchased part of the inventory on credit.

The business is going well, but Mushvig decided to increase his inventory through an infusion of capital which he would like to get in the form of a loan. For this purpose, he has turned to the local affiliate of Normicro with a request for a $500 loan.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Шахбазов Мушвиг живет в пригороде Саатлы Республики Азербайджан расположенном в Южном Кавказе. Он женат, ему 28 лет. 10 лет тому назад он начал свой бизнес, арендовав маркет в городе Саатлы. Имея свои собственные сбережения, он наполнис его товаром. Часть товара он взял в кредит. Несмотря на то, что торговля идет хорошо, Мушвиг решил увеличить оборот своего капитала за счет инвестиции, которую он хочет сделать в форме полученного кредита. Поэтому он обратился с заявлением к местному филлиалу микро кредитной организации "Нормикро" с просьбой о предоставлении ему кредита в 500 долларов.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Ivodia

texts.en:
Ivodia is a widow and a mother of one child, and also cares for her late brother's three children.  She has faced challenges in her life which include the death of her husband, her mother and her brother.  

With the heavy responsibility of having to take care of these children single handedly, she decided to seek a loan from GHAPE and start a business.

With a loan of $100, she plans to cultivate and sell crops as she already owns a piece of farmland.  The profit will be used to pay school fees for her children, provide other basic needs for her children and invest back in her business.

She plans to repay the loan in 15 months with the first installment on the day the loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of manure, transport and seeds to start farming

loans.name: Desak Suarsi

texts.id:
Desak Suardi is a widow with 1 daughter. Desak lives alone now since her daughter is already married and living with her husband. Her house is very simple with ground flooring and its wall is made from bamboo. Despite these circumstances, Desak Suardi still has a strong heart to handle the harsh life. She has pig farm as her only business. With the help of DINARI, she bought 2 pig babies which cost Rp. 450,000 (about $50). Every evening she prepares the pig food for the evening and the morning. She feeds the pigs twice a day; at 4pm and 8am. She does these routines with diligence and she hopes she can quickly sell the pigs. In 3 months, she could sell the pigs with total price Rp. 1,300,000 (about $143.4). She got Rp.500,000 (about $55) net profit after deducting the pig food expenses. This profit is very useful to cover her daily life expenses. For the next loan, she will use it to buy 4 more baby pigs to gain more revenue.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Desak Suarsi adalah seorang janda dengan satu anak perempuan. Karena anaknya sudah menikah dan ikut dengan suaminaya maka saat ini Desak Suarsi tinggal hanya sendirian. Rumahnya sangat sederhana lantai masih terbuat dari tanah, tembok dinding hanya terbuat dari bambu yang dianyam-anyam dan lantai tanah. Walau demikian Desak Suarsi tetap tegar dalam menghadapi perjalan hidupnya yang memprihatinkan. Kegiatan usaha yang ditekuninya hanyalah beternak babi. Dengan bantuan dari Yayasan DINARI Desak Suarsi membeli 2 bibit babi dengan total harga Rp. 450.000,-.Setiap sore Desak Suarsi meracik pakan untuk sore hari dan pagi harinya. Pemberian pakan dilakukan sehari 2 kali yaitu sore pukul 16 wita dan pagi hari pukul 08.00 wita. Hari demi hari kegiatan rutin ini dikakukan dengan tekun, dengan harapan ke 2 babinya cepat bisa dipanen/dijual. Panen dilakukan setelah pemeliharaan bejalan 3 bulan dengan total penjualan Rp.1.300.000.- Keuntungan bersih yang didapat sebesar Rp. 500.000.- setelah dikurangi biaya pakan. Keuntungan tersebut sangat berarti bagi Desak Suarsi sebab dapat membantu pendataan untuk dapat mencukupi kebutuhan hidup sehari - hari. Rencana untuk pinjaman berikutnya akan membeli 4 ekor bibit babi agar keuntungan semakin meningkat lagi.

loans.use: To add growing pigs

loans.name: Abbasov

texts.en:
Mr. A. is a low income vulnerable person. He is 32, married with 2 children, and lives in the Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in Caucasus region.

A. and his wife (she is pictured) have owned and operated a small food market in the local bazaar of Saatli town for 10 years. The business is stable because A. has built up his customers during the time he has run the shop. But there is no money to diversify the assortment and increase sales, and therefore no income to provide all the necessities of life for his children.

Some commercial banks demand collateral to give him credit, but A. has nothing to mortgage. That's why he applied to Normicro Saatli branch, which disburses credit free of collateral, for a $500 loan. This credit could let him buy and sell larger amount of goods and develop business.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Soleha

texts.id:
Mr. Soleha has a business making weaving products. He lives in a rented home at Rp3,000,000 (about US$330)/year. His wife and daughter live with him. His sales is about Rp5,000,000- Rp7,000,000 (about US$550-770)/month. His nett profit could reach Rp1,000,000 (about $110)/month. At this moment he has 4 employees at a monthly salary of Rp600,000 (about $66)/person. Loan to be obtained would be used to buy weaving raw materials like rattan and bamboo. His assumption is that profit could increase to about Rp1,500,000 ($165)/month. So far the raw materials he bought are finished products. Monthly living expenses are Rp 750,000 (about $82.50), and child education expense of Rp60,000 (about $6.60)/month could be afforded. Larger capital would help in expansion of his business,

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Bapak Soleha mempunyai usaha membuat kerei (anyaman). Dia tinggal di rumah kontrakan Rp 3.000.000,00 per tahunnya. Istri dan satu putrinya tinggal bersamanya. Omzet penjualannya Rp 5.000.000,00 – Rp 7.000.000,00/bulan. Keuntungan bersih per bulannya mencapai Rp 1.000.000,00. Saat ini dia memiliki 4 anak buah dengan gaji per bulan Rp 600.000,00 per orang. Pinjaman yang diperoleh akan digunakan untuk membeli bahan mentah kerei, seperti rotan dan bambu. Asumsinya keuntungan akan bertambah ± Rp 1.500.000,00/bulan. Karena selama ini bahan baku yang dia beli, berupa bahan yang sudah jadi. Biaya hidup per bulan Rp 750.000,00 dan biaya pendidikan anak per bulan Rp 60.000,00 dapat dia cukupi. Modal yang besar tentu akan membantu perkembangan usahanya.

loans.use:
To buy weaving raw materials like rattan & bamboo

Membeli bahan mentah kerei, seperti rotan dan bambu

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Awah

texts.en:
Awah Janet is married and is a mother of one child.  Growing up, she was not privileged enough to get basic education because her polygamous father could not pay her school fees.  Now, at the age of 23 years, she still plans to continue her education.  However, she lacks the money for school fees.

With a loan of $100, she plans to invest in her grocery business so she can raise enough money to sponsor herself in school.

She plans to repay the loan in 15 months with the first installment on the day the loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Invest in her grocery business to raise money for school

loans.name: Keyyar

texts.en:
Keyyar H. is 34 years old. He is from the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory Gubadli region, situated in the western part of Azerbaijan. Keyyar began his business 10 years ago. He is the only income earner of his family. He started his business in 1997, when he purchased small variety of clothes.

In 2004, Keyyar borrowed US$ 400 to add to his own savings of $200 and purchased another sort of sport clothes. The second time, Keyyar applied for a loan of $800 from Normicro to expand his business. The loans were paid back in a timely manner. Keyyar wants expand his business and to begin selling shoes.

He needs a $1,200 loan in order to further develop his business, to buy other clothes, to begin selling shoes and expand his shop to increase his business and to improve his family’s living conditions with this additional income.

loans.use: To buy clothes, to begin selling shoes and expand his shop

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
B. Rachel is a seamstress who has faced difficulties making a profit because she lacked enough capital to invest in the business.  Hearing of GHAPE, she excitedly decided to join and was trained in business management skills and credit discipline.

With a loan of $100, she plans to start a business sewing and selling dresses.  She believes the business will succeed because she already owns a sewing machine and has been trained as a seamstress.  The money raised will be used to invest back into the business and to pay school fees for her daughter.

She plans to repay the loan in 15 months with the first installment on the day the loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of cloth, sewing threads and to pay taxes

loans.name: Suh Emmanuel

texts.en:
The untimely death of Emmanuel’s father left him alone to fend for himself at a very tender age.  At the age of 16 years, he started his business of selling cosmetics and since then, the business has been striving.
