As a member of the Matafaa Center, Seutaatia maintains her focus on her family, which she struggles daily to support. With rising prices and community commitments from her village, it is tough to make ends meet. Seutaatia pushes herself as hard as she can to improve her family’s living conditions.

She hasthree kids who are working, but their family’s main income is from fishing, which her husband is locally renowned for because of his excellent catches. He goes fishing twice per week, while she does the selling. This earns them a profit of $350 USD after all costs.

She is able to continue borrowing from SPBD to support her family and to save extra money for her future plans. These plans involve buying a fishing boat to increase their income and improve living conditions. This is her dream and it motivates her to keep working hard.

loans.use: To buy cement, timber, and fishing nets

loans.name: Melisa

texts.en:
Melisa’s husband has a very good job at the Central Bank but because of the high cost of living (especially with four kids to feed and put through school), she got the idea of starting up her own business to improve her family life.

Her grocery shop opens seven days a week from 6am- 8.pm daily. She focuses more on foods and her prices are very competitive and fair. There is a high demand for her goods from her customers, who mostly come from the local village. It also saves her customers the trouble and expense of having to travel all the way from the village into town.

She makes about $72 USD per day after all expenses of restocking, bills, and looking after her family. Her aim is to expand her shop into a mini-mart.

loans.use: To restock her shop and for home improvements

loans.name: Patisepa

texts.en:
On Fridays, if you go by the Fugalei market, you will always be greeted by Patisepa with a huge smile. This is the day when she sells her two sacks of taros, which are so high in quality that there are never any left after just three hours.

Afterwards, she heads home to set up her weekly budget and helps get her husband's fishing gear ready. This is their second source of income; her husband fishes every Saturday, and Matafaa sells the catch early Sunday mornings. The fish is usually sold out in only one hour, despite the huge competition.

With a big family of seven kids, her aim is to provide them with the education that she and her husband had never received. Her children can eventually become financially independent. Currently, she makes a weekly profit of $160 USD.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, tools , knives, cement, and timber.

loans.name: Malo

texts.en:
Malo makes confectioneries such as ice cake and ice blocks, which are very popular with the local villagers, especially children. Selling for a cheap price, which ranges from $0.20 to $0.40, her products are getting more popular day by day.

This business has inspired her to work harder and to make an extra batch of 20 confectioneries. She has no trouble selling these. She delivers and sells her items from home, and earns $120 USD per week excluding costs. She is able to support her family of five and plans to receive another loan with SPBD.

loans.use: To buy plastic bags, kool aid, sugar, and other supplies, as well as  supplies for home improvement

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos O. is an Acholi by tribe. He came to Kampala from the Pader districts of Northern Uganda due to wars in the region making it unsafe to stay in his village. From the northern region, he settled in Banda Acholi Quarters in Kampala where he started working in the stone quarry. He later was brought by his friend to join Life in Africa Foundation and started making paper beads and also got a job as a security guard. According to him, his life has changed for the better.

Amos’s stone quarry is now in high demand. There is a lot of construction and renovation in Kampala and the gravel needs are large. So he wants to double his profits by making more trips. He used to make 90,000/= (about US$50) in profit from two trips per month, and now he is requesting a loan of 250,000/= (US$150) to expand his business to four trips per month. He feels sure he will be able to repay this loan in 3 months.

Below is his budget:

-Extraction ……………………. 90,000/=

-Breaking ………………………30,000/=

-Carrying out of the pit…………40,000/=

-Crouching to aggregates ……….90, 000/=

Total …………………………….250, 000/=

loans.use: Employing laborers

loans.name: Pelesa

texts.en:
Pelesa, 62 years of age, is well-known for her pancakes. She delivers these pancakes to the local schools and sells them to her fellow villagers and family members. Pelesa finds herself too old for heavy labor, which is why she got into the pancakes business.

Her pancakes are not plain; she adds additional flavors by making them with banana and raspberry, which has kept her customers coming back for more! She is able to earn $80 USD per week in profit, which is more than enough to improve her six-member family’s standard of living as well as help her children obtain a good education.

loans.use: To buy supplies for making pancakes and for home improvement

loans.name: Sitoga

texts.en:
Sitoga’s goal is to provide her family with good living conditions and her children with an education. She has three kids to put through school, and has barely enough money to put food on the table.

These circumstances have made her determined to join SPBD to seek out a loan in order to improve her husband’s taro plantation. They work six days a week planting and harvesting, while on Fridays, they sell their taro at the Fugalei Market. They have increased their earnings to $220 USD per week by selling two to three sacks of taro per week from the one sack per week they were selling before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, tools , knives, cement, and timber.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian A. is an Acholi by tribe and was born in 1955. She is a married lady with four children. When the 20-year-war in the north became unavoidable, life was difficult and many lost their lives or were displaced. Lilian, for fear of her life, had to take refugee in Kampala in August 2000. On her arrival in Kampala the only place to settle in was Acholi Quarters which is on one of the hills that the King of Buganda offered to the refugees.

It was Lilian's first time to be in the city and the way of life became difficult. No way to grow your own food, no barter or trade, and no free things. To survive here you needed money and she had none. The option for Lilian was to involve herself in stone quarry activities that helped her generate a little capital. Then she found the Life in Africa Foundation and was able to earn some money participating in the craft programs.

Lilian now wants to supplement her income by starting a petty business as a fish monger. Fish is a big part of the diet and is always in demand so she is confident that she will be able to be successful. She is seeking a loan in the amount of 250,000/= (US$ 150) and she feels sure she will be able to repay this loan in 6 months.

Below is her budget:

Putting up a basic roof for shade………………………………………..30,000/=
Buying a container for keeping fish…………………10,000/=

Transport …………………………………………….10, 000/=

Buying fish ……………………………………….200, 000/=

Total………………………………………………250,000/=

loans.use: Buying fish for re-sale

loans.name: Anasitasia

texts.en:
Anasitasia’s husband is a carpenter. Unfortunately, the wages are low for carpentry assistants, and her husband does not run his own business. Anasitasia took out a loan from SPBD and started up her own vegetable garden - a true passion of hers. 

She grows all sorts of vegetables, which she tends and maintains to give them an extra tasty quality. With four kids to feed, clothe, and put through school, she dreams of improving their living conditions. She also hopes to provide them with a higher level of education so that they can be successful and financially independent. 

She delivers to shops, supermarkets, and sells directly at the market. She is currently making a profit of $60 USD per week, and is looking to expand her business. Possibly, she may open up a hotel and restaurant in the future.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, tools, knives, cement, and timber.

loans.name: Yuliati

texts.id:
Ms. Yuliati is a persistent housewife. Newcomer from Java island, she lives in a rented home for Rp125,000 (about US$13.75)/month with husband and three children. She is selling vegetables around the neighborhood on a modified motorcycle. Every day she needs Rp500,000.00-Rp750,000.00 (around $55-$83) for a nett profit of Rp50,000.00 (about $5.50). She is doing this work to add family income. Ms. Yuliati's husband is in the buying & selling motor, and a workshop business with a profit of Rp1,000,000.00 (about $110)/month. Monthly expenses a month of Rp750,000.00 (about $82.50), and children's education expenses of Rp120,000.00 (about $13.20) are her reasons. The loan will be used in her vegetable sales business; also to finance the motor buying & selling and the workshop. Ms. Yuliati hopes the loan could increase the sales volume, so that her profit could increase to Rp75,000.00 (about $8.25)/day, and her husband's business to Rp1,500.000.00 (about $165)/month.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ibu Yuliati adalah seorang ibu rumah tangga yang ulet. Pendatang dari pulau jawa ini tinggal di sebuah rumah kontrakan Rp 125.000,00/bulan bersama suami dan tiga orang anaknya. Dia berjualan sayur keliling dengan sepeda motor yang sedikit dimodifikasi. Setiap harinya dia membutuhkan modal Rp 500.000,00 – Rp 750.000,00 dan mendapatkan untung bersih Rp 50.000,00. Usaha ini dia tekuni untuk membantu menambah penghasilan keluarga. Suami Bu Yuliati memiliki usaha jual beli motor dan bengkel dengan keuntungan Rp 1.000.000,00/bulan. Biaya hidup per bulan Rp 750.000,00 dan biaya pendidikan anak per bulan Rp 120.000,00 menjadi salah satu alasannya. Pinjaman yang diperoleh akan digunakan untuk usaha jual sayur ; juga usaha jual beli motor dan bengkel. Ibu Yuliati berharap pinjaman yang diperoleh mampu menambah omzet penjualannya, sehingga keuntungannya menjadi Rp 75.000,00/hari dan keuntungan usaha suaminya menjadi Rp 1.500.000,00/bulan.

loans.use:
To buy vegetables and capital increase for buy and sell of motor and workshop (husband's)

Membeli sayuran dan tambahan modal usaha jual beli motor dan bengkel (Suami)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen A. is a married woman with eight children who are all of school-going age. She was originally from Northern Uganda but she came to Kampala in 1996 when Northern Uganda was experiencing Kony's rebel activities. This forced her to move her family away from the region and they settled in an IDP camp known as the Acholi Quarters.

When Hellen settled in Acholi quarters, life was not easy. The only real source of income was to work in the rock quarry. Later she joined the Life in Africa Foundation and was able to participate in the paper bead project which has enabled her to make additional income. But she and her husband are working hard and are always looking for ways to increase the income that sustains their large family.

They have acquired a plot in the Acholi Quarters and their plan is to construct a simple mud two-room house that they will rent out. Housing is in high demand and they will be able to rent each room out for 20,000/= (about US$ 12) per month. This will increase their income by 40,000/= each month which will improve the family's standard of living. It will only take two weeks to build the house and they can have tenants move in within two days.

Hellen and her husband have saved 300,000/= and are now seeking a loan in the amount of 250,000/= (US$ 150) to add on and make their plan happen. They feel sure they will be able to repay this loan in 6 months.

Below is their budget:

10 iron sheets of 23 guage @ 13,000..........................130,000/=

Roofing poles ..............................................................40,000/=

3 bags of cement for plastering and flooring @ 24,000/-.................72,000/=

Mud for walls .....................................................................................100,000/=

Half pick-up of sand .......................................................................30,000/=

3 kgs of nails.....................................................................................7000/=

Labor for roofing and plastering.........................................................100,000/=

Transport...........................................................................21,000/=

Total ............................................................................... 500,000/=

loans.use: buying material for building a house to rent out

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine A. is an Acholi from Gulu. She was forced to move away from there due to the war in the region. She resettled in the IDP camp called the Acholi Quarters and started working in the stone quarry to earn money.

Catherine joined Life in Africa Foundation in 2005 and got involved in the community recycling activities. Catherine is a very hard-working person and has a good business mind. She noticed that at the stone quarry, people seemed to be so busy that they could not go back to their homes for lunch. She did a survey and found that many would like to have an eating joint nearby. She feels this would not only be making her an income but would also be serving the community.

A food business is one of the things that will never lack customers. Catherine has managed to put up a simple structure for her little restaurant and has also acquired benches. Now she needs to buy foodstuffs and utensils. She is therefore seeking a loan amounting to 250,000/= (US$ 150) that she plans to repay in six months.

Here is the budget for her business:

5 kgs of meat @ 3000....................................................15,000/=

10 kgs of beans @ 1000....................................................10,000/=

2 sacks of charcoal............................................................50,000/=

20 Plates @ 2000 each .......................................................40,000/=

20 plastic cups @ 500 each......................................................10,000/=

5 saucepans @ 10,000 ......................................................50,000/=

5 kgs of rice @ 1500 ..........................................................7500/=

5 kgs maize flour @ 1000 ..................................................5000/=

1 bunch of bananas@............................................................8000/=

carpet.....................................................................................15,000/=

5 liters of cooking oil............................................................22,500/=

diverse ...................................................................................15,000/=

Total approximately............................................................250,000/=

loans.use: Buying foodstuffs, etc. for her little restaurant

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. is a Muganda by tribe and a business lady. She joined Life in Africa Foundation in 2006 where she worked on the Invisible Children bracelet project. She has already recieved a Kiva loan of 800,000/= to start a retail business selling shoes. Her repayment record is good.

To increase her income Annet would like to expand her business by selling soft drinks. She has room at her stall in town to put a fridge and since cold drinks are in demand, this business will do well.

To make this expansion Annet is seeking a loan in the amount of 250,000/= (US$ 150) to finance the purchase of a second-hand medium-sized fridge and some crates of soda. She feels sure she will be able repay this loan in three months. Here is her budget:

A second-hand fridge .........................................................200,000/=

Two crates of soda @ 10,000/-..........................................20,000/=

Three cartons of Safi drinks ...................................................15,000/=

Passion fruit .............................................................................8,000/=

Buying used plastic bottles for bottling passion fruit juce..............5,000/=

1 kg of sugar.....................................................................................2,000/=

Total....................................................................................................250,000/=

loans.use: Buying second-hand fridge and soft drinks

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sitri

texts.id:
Ni Ketut Sitri besides being a hosuwife also helps her husband I Wayan Lungguh as a tenant farmer. To fulfill family needs Ni Ketut Sitri raises 1 mother pig, and 3 piglets for fattening. With a capital of Rp1,500,000 (about US$165) to buy pig feed, Ni Ketut Sitri could profit Rp200,000 (about $22)/month. Ketut Sitri feed her pigs 2X/day at 8:00 AM and 4:00PM. Before feeding, she bathe her pigs first, and clean the stall. Ni Ketut Sitri lives in her home with her child who finished highschool. With this business, Ni Ketut Sitri is optimistic it would increase her living standard. Therefore she is persistent and not giving up hope. One thing she believes is that everything done well will give good final results.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Ketut Sitri disamping sebagai ibu rumah tangga, juga membantu suaminya I Wayan Lungguh yang bekerja sebagai petani. Untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya Ni Ketut Sitri memelihara 1 induk babi dan 3 ekor babi untuk penggemukan. Dengan modal Rp.1.500.000.- digunakan untuk membeli pakan babi, Ni Ketut Sitri mendapat keuntungan Rp. 200.000,- perbulan. Ketut Sitri memberi makan babinya dua kali sehari pada pagi hari jam 08:00 pagi dan pada sore hari jam 16.00 wita. Sebelum memberi makan, babinya dimandikan dulu dan kandangnya dibersihkan sampai bersih. Ni Ketut Sitri tinggal dirumahnya bersama dengan anaknya yang sudah tamat sekolah SMA. Dengan usaha yang dimilikinya sekarang, Ni Ketut Sitri optimis akan dapat meningkatkan taraf hidupnya. Oleh karena itu, usahanya ini dilakukannya dengan semangat dan tidak putus asa. Satu hal yang diyakini Ni Ketut Sitri bahwa segala sesuatu bila dilakukan dengan tekun akan mendapatkan hasil akhir yang baik.

loans.use:
To buy pig feed

Membeli pakan babi

loans.name: Ni Wayan Wenen

texts.id:
Besides a tenant farmer, Wenen also help family finances by raising 4 fattening pigs. Wenen is persistent in her work. Every morning at 8:00AM Wenen feeds her pigs. Before feeding she bathe her pigs first, and also clean the stall. Evenings at 4:00 PM Wenen again feeds her pigs. Capital needed of Rp 1,300,000 (Us$143) are neede to buy pig feed and medicine. Profit could be as high as Rp200,000 ($22)/month. With that profit Wenen could help her husband to finance the family needs. Although the two children finished highschool, they are still unmarried, and live at home. Daily living expenses are about Rp20,000 (US$2.20). The house is built on own land, but the building is semi permanent. Wenen's hope is that with the expected capital received, her business could prosper, and a better family living.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Selain sebagai petani, Wenen juga membantu penghasilan keluarga dengan memelihara babi penggemukan sejumlah 4 ekor. Wenen sangat tekun dengan pekerjaannya. Setiap pagi pukul 8.00 Wenen memberi makan babinya. Sebelum diberi makan, babi-babinya dimandikan dahulu dan kandangnya juga dibersihkan. Pada sore hari jam 16.00 Wenen kembali memberi makan babinya. Modal yang dibutuhkan Rp. 1.300.000 untuk memelihara 4 ekor babi. Semua modal itu dipergunakan untuk membelikan pakan dan juga obat – obatan. Keuntungan yang diperoleh sebesar Rp. 200.000.- perbulan. Dengan keuntungan yang diperoleh Wenen, bisa membantu suaminya untuk menghidupi keluarganya.Walaupun kedua anaknya sudah tamat sekolah SMA, namun mereka belum ada yang menikah, sehingga masih menjadi tanggungan keluarga . Biaya hidup sehari-hari yang diperlukan Rp. 20.000.- Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri dengan bangunan yang semi permanen. Harapan Wenen dengan modal yang diperoleh usahanya menjadi maju dan kehidupan keluarga lebih baik.

loans.use:
To buy pig feed and medicine

Membeli pakan babi dan obat -obatan

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce M. is a Muganda by tribe and a craft maker. She is one of the active members of Life in Africa Foundation. She does many handicrafts like table cloths, wall hangings, etc. She is one of the first Kiva borrowers who took a loan of 800.000/= to buy materials for crafts. Joyce is doing well and from the profits she made, there was no problem with her repayment.

Joyce is now hoping to sell to visitors at the Heads of Commonwealth meeting to be held on the 23 Novermber in Uganda where over 5000 delegates are expected to attend. She is a member of the American Club where most African crafts are sold and has high expectations of excellent sales.

According to Joyce's calculations, this Heads of Government meeting might triple normal sales and so she does not want to run out of stock during this money-making period. Any stock left over will be sold at the regular market.

To make this expansion possible, Joyce is seeking a loan in the amount of 250,000/= (US$ 150) and she feels sure she will be able to repay this loan in 4 months.

Below is her budget:

Table cloth/materials etc. ..............................................150,000/=

4 rolls of thread.................................................................................80,000/=

Backcloth for wall hangings............................................................20,000/=

Total ....................................................................................................250,000/=

loans.use: Restocking a craft shop

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is an Acholi by tribe, aged 30 years. She was forced to flee her home in the north due to the war and she lives in an IDP camp known as the Acholi Quarters. It was here that she met her husband who is Mucholi and they have been blessed by God with two children. Rose says she is afraid to return to the north until a firm peace agreement has been reached.

Like most Acholis in the camp Rose labors in the stone quarry to earn a living. She is also an active member of Life in Africa Foundation where she earns some money in the bead-making program. She already owns her own plot in the quarry but would like to expand to earn more income.

With this new business Rose will not only increase her own income but she will be able to create some jobs for other people living at the camp. She believes it is a good time to cash in on all the construction and renovation going on in Kampala right now. She plans to make two trips each month which will earn a profit of 50,000/= (about US$ 28) per trip after all expenses.

To do this Rose is seeking a loan in the amount of 250,000/= (US$ 150) and she feels sure she will be able to repay this loan in 6 months.

Below is her budget:

-Removing soil from pit…………………………50,000/=

-Extraction of 2 trips of stone…………………50,000/=

-Breaking …………………………………………30,000/=

-Breaking into aggregates ………………………..80,000/=

-Buying more tools like a big hammer, 5 chisels…..40,000/=

Total ………………………………………………250,000/=

loans.use: Paying for labour, etc.

loans.name: Ni Made Lina Rahayu

texts.id:
Living in Manistutu village (West Bali) made Ni Made Lina Rahayu to channel her hobby as pig farmer. Lina raised a mother pig and a fattening piglet. Lina is persistent in feeding her pigs at 8:00 AM and 4:00 PM, before feeding she bathe her pigs until clean, and also clean their stall. Capital needed by Lina is Rp1,300,000 (about US$143) and expected profit is Rp200,000 (about $22)/month. From that profit Lina could help her husband Gede Juan who works in a workshop. Lina has a young child, 2.5 years old. Lina is working hard, so that she could save for her child's education in the future. Lina's semi permanent home is owned in own land. Daily expenses are Rp25,000 (about US$2.75). Lina's hope is with the expected capital, her profit could increase and her life could be better.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Tinggal di Desa Manistutu ( Bali Barat ) membuat Ni Made Lina Rahayu bisa menyalurkan hobinya sebagi peternak babi . Lina memelihara 1 induk babi dan 1 babi penggemukan . Lina dengan tekun memberi makan babinya pada pagi hari jam 08.00 dan sore hari pukul 16.00 wita, sebelum diberi makan babi-babinya dimandikan sampai bersih dan juga Lina tak lupa membersihkan kandangnya. Modal yang Lina perlukan Rp.1.300.000.- dan keuntungan yang diperoleh Rp. 200.000.- perbulan. Dengan keuntungan yang diperoleh Lina bisa membantu suaminya Gede Juan yang bekerja sebagai bengkel. Lina mempunyai seorang anak yang masih kecil , umurnya 2,5 tahun. Lina dengan semangat bekerja agar bisa menabung untuk pendidikan anaknya kelak. Rumah Lina sudah milik sendiri ditanah sendiri dan bangunannya semi permanen. Biaya yang dibutuhkan untuk kebutuhan sehari-hari sebesar Rp. 25.000.- Harapan Lina dengan modal yang diperoleh keuntungan bisa bertambah dan hidupnya bisa jauh lebih baik.

loans.use:
To buy pig's feed

Membeli pakan ternak babi

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 26 years old. He has two children. His mother and father are living with him, and he is responsible for their living expenses. He has a butcher shop in Kirkuk. He wants to borrow $1200 to purchase a new ice box for the shop and renovate the shop by painting it in order to increase his income and expand his business.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new ice box for the shop

loans.name: Ni Ketut Astuti

texts.id:
Ketut Astuti besides being a housewife also has a pig farming business. Ketut Astuti helps her husband Made Widiarsa who works as a tenant farmer to support family needs and education of their 3 school age children. With a capital of Rp 1,500,000 (about US$165) Ketut raised 2 mother pigs that already produce 16 piglets. Some were already sold to customers. Today Ni Ketut Astuti left 4 piglets to be fattened. Her profit is Rp 250,000 (about $27.50)/month. Besides feeding with rice shell and wheat shell clippings, she also fed greeneries like banana leaves, talas leaves and banana tree trunk. Ni Ketut Astuti fed her pigs 2X/day at 8:00 AM and 4:00 PM. Ni Ketut Astuti lives in own home that was built with her husband and the building is quite permanent. Ni Ketut Astuti hopes that the would be recived capital could expand her business, and her family well being.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ketut Astuti disamping sebagai ibu rumah tangga, juga mempunyai usaha memelihara babi . Ketut Astuti membantu suaminya Made Widiarsa yang bekerja sebagai petani , untuk mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya dan pendidikan ketiga anaknya yang masih sekolah. Dengan modal Rp.1.500.000,- Ketut memelihara 2 induk dan sudah mempunyai 16 anak. Sebagian sudah dijual kepada langganannya. Sekarang Ni Ketut Astuti masih menyisakan 4 anak babinya untuk dipelihara sebagai penggemukan. Keuntungan yang diperoleh Rp. 250.000,- perbulan. Disamping memberi dedak padi dan dedak gandum, juga diberikan makanan hijauan seperti daun pisang, daun talas, dan batang pisang. Ni Ketut Astuti memberi makan babinya dua kali sehari pada pagi hari jam 08:00 pagi dan sore hari jam 16:00 wita. Ni Ketut Astuti tinggal dirumah sendiri yang dibangun bersama dengan suaminya dan bangunannya cukup permanen. Ni Ketut Astuti berharap agar modal yang diperoleh dapat mengembangkan usahanya dan juga kesejahteraan keluarganya.

loans.use:
To buy pig's feed

Membeli pakan ternak

loans.name: Dibe

texts.en: Dibe is a 22-year-old woman. She lives in the region of Tyre and works in the agriculture sector, growing vegetables in greenhouses. Dibe is divorced and lives on her own. She is striving to ensure a decent living. She is taking the initiative to expand her business by buying sheep in order to generate more revenue, which will allow her to stay financially independent.

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Ni Nengah Nuitri

texts.id:
Ni Nengah Nuitri, 56 years old lives in Manistutu, a village in West Bali, where most inhabitants profession are tenant farmers. So is Ni Nengah Nuitri profession. The last few months the weather was in a quite long dry season, so that farm produce was down. But living expenses increase. As a Balinese woman, and a good mother, Ni Nengah Nuitri quickly grasp the situation. To support from not so good economic condition, Ni Nengah Nuitri covered it from her pig farming business. The loan would be used to buy a mother pig. She has been in this business since getting married, and she is still on it. Ni Nengah Nuitri wants to change her life, as mopther and wife. Ni Nengah Nuitri won't only depend on her husband's income. Ni Nengah Nuitri wants to increase her living standard as a woman or wife. With her pig farming business, Ni Nengah Nuitri has her own income to support family expenses. Her husband is also supportive at her business venture.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Nengah Nuitri, 56 tahun, tinggal di desa Manistutu, sebuah desa di Bali barat yang sebagian besar penduduknya berprofesi sebagai petani. Demikian juga yang dikerjakan oleh Ni Nengah Nuitri. Beberapa bulan terakhir, kondisi cuaca didaerah ini mengalami musim kering yang cukup panjang sehingga mengakibatkan penurunan dari hasil pertanian. Sedangkan biaya hidup semakin tinggi. Sebagai seorang wanita Bali dan ibu rumah tangga yang baik, Ni Nengah Nuitri cepat tanggap akan situasi itu. Untuk menunjang dari situasi ekonomi yang kurang baik, Ni Nengah Nuitri menutupinya dengan penghasilannya dari beternak babi. Pinjaman yang diperolehnya digunakan untuk membeli induk babi. Usaha ini sudah ditekuninya sejak ia menikah dulu. Kegiatan ini tetap dilakukannya, karena Ni Nengah Nuitri mempunyai semangat untuk merubah hidupnya, baik sebagai ibu rumah tangga atau sebagi istri. Ni Nengah Nuitri tidak ingin hanya meminta mengandalkan pendapatan suaminya untuk keperluan hidup berkeluarga. Ni Nengah Nuitri ingin mengangkat derajat hidupnya sebagi seorang wanita atau istri. Dengan usaha ternak babi yang kini ditekuninya, Ni Nengah Nuitri mempunyai penghasilan sendiri yang dapat menunjang penghasilan keluarganya. Suaminya pun sangat mendukungnya atas usaha yang dilakukannya.

loans.use:
To buy mother pig

Membeli induk babi

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ghazwa

texts.en: Ghazwa is a 32-year-old woman who lives with her family in the region of Tyre. She and her siblings are working to support their family. She is now employed in a pharmacy at a part-time job. The money she earns helps her family, but Ghazwa is also committed to pursuing her studies and getting a degree in history. She therefore needs $500 to enroll in her fourth year at the university. Ghazwa believes that education is the best means to a decent and independent life.

loans.use: To pay her tuition fees

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Sunantri

texts.id:
Ni Nyoman Sunantri, a widow lives by herself in a simple home. Her house is made from unplastered batako, and cement floor. Her husband passed away 5 years ago, due to sickness. She lives with a child who is in college. To pay for living expenses, and child's college expenses, Ni Nyoman Sunantri is in the pig farming business. She is doing this business, since Ni Nyoman Sunantri sees a quite good opportunity in marketing pigs of roasted piglets (a Balinese specialty: after 3 months, ready to harvest), so that her investmet could circle faster. With the loan, Ni Nyoman Sunantri increase her business truely. Besides buying a mother pig, Ni Nyoman Sunantri also would add to her stall, so that the pregnat mother pig would have a place for her piglets. Ni Nyoman Sunantri works hard on this business to obtain maximal results. All this was done to support her child's education, to obtain education as high as possible. Ni Nyoman Sunantri is convince and hope that with higher education, her child could be succesful, helping family and mankind.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Nyoman Sunantri, seorang janda yang tinggal seorang diri dirumahnya yang sederhana. Rumahnya terbuat dari batako yang belum diplester dan berlantai semen. Suaminya sudah meninggal dunia 5 tahun lalu, karena menderita sakit. Saat ini ia hidup dengan seorang anaknya yang sekarang sudah menimba ilmu di perguruan tinggi. Untuk menunjang biaya hidup dan biaya kuliah anaknya, Ni Nyoman Sunantri melakukan usaha ternak babi. Usaha ini dtekuninya karena Ni Nyoman Sunantri melihat peluang yang cukup baik dipemasaran babi untuk jenis babi guling ( 3 bulan pemeliharaan, siap panen ) sehingga perputaran dana lebih cepat. Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya, Ni Nyoman Sunantri meningkatkan usahanya dengan sungguh – sungguh. Selain membelikan induk babi, Ni Nyoman Sunantri juga menambah lokasi kandangnya sehingga induk babi yang akan melahirkan mempunyai tempat untuk anak – anaknya. Ni Nyoman Sunantri menekuni usaha ini dengan kerja keras karena ia menginginkan hasil yang maksimal. Semua itu dilakukan untuk menunjang pendidikan anaknya agar dapat menempuh pendidikan setinggi mungkin. Ni Nyoman Sunantri meyakini dan berharap, dengan pendidikan yang semakin tinggi, anaknya akan menjadi orang yang sukses yang dapat membantu keluarga dan sesamanya.

loans.use:
To buy a mother pig and build a stall

Membeli induk babi dan membuat kandang

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 25 years old. He lives with his wife and two children in a rented house. One of his children is going to school. The borrower has an electronics shop in Kirkuk. He applied to borrow $1200 to purchase new electronic goods for the shop and paint the shop with some advertising to increase his income and develop his business. He wants to save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new electronic goods

loans.name: Ridwan

texts.id:
This time Ridwan has a motorcycle taxi business. Every day he works from the Ubung terminal from mornings to evenings. His nett profit is about Rp25,000.00 (about US$2.75)/day. His numbers are calculated after he subtracted operational expenses, for gasoline of about Rp25,000.00 ($2.75)/day. The expected loan, would be used to buy a motor cycle. He sees an opportunity for motor cycle taxi at night. If he could do this, his nett income could increase to between Rp25,000.00-Rp50,000.00 (about $2.75-$5.50)/day. Ridwan lives in a rented home with his wife and 2 children. This business are the only income for Ridwan family, since his wife is jobless. Daily living expenses are Rp20,000.00 ($2.20), and children education expenses are Rp60,000.00 (about $6.60)/month. He has to work very hard for it.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Saat ini Ridwan mempunyai usaha tukang ojek. Setiap harinya dia bertempat di terminal Ubung dari pagi sampai sore hari. Keuntungan bersihnya mencapai Rp 25.000,00/hari. Angka itu diperoleh setelah dipotong biaya operasional, yaitu bensin ± Rp 25.000,00/hari. Pinjaman yang diperoleh akan dipakai untuk membeli sepeda motor. Dia melihat peluang untuk ngojek di malam hari. Apabila dia melakukannya, penghasilan bersihnya bisa mencapai Rp 25.000,00 – RP 50.000,00 per harinya. Ridwan tinggal di rumah kontrakkan bersama isteri dan kedua anaknya. Usaha ini merupakan satu-satunya tumpuan harapan bagi Ridwan sekeluarga, karena isterinya tidak bekerja. Biaya hidup per hari Rp 20.000,00 dan biaya pendidikan anak Rp 60.000,00 per bulan. Dia harus kerja keras untuk itu.

loans.use:
To buy a motorcycle

Membeli sepeda motor

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long N. T. supports his wife and three children by working in a brick shop. His wife does housework and cares for their youngest son who is one year old, while his nine year old and three year old go to school. Mr. T. would like to borrow $75 to raise chickens so he can increase his income to pay tuition for his children’s school. He will pay the loan back over the next 4 months.

loans.use: raise chicken

loans.name: Long

texts.en: The father works as day labor and helps his wife, who sells rice noodles. Their two children (7 and 5 years old) are in school. They want to borrow $62.5 to add to their capital to get more income to support their family. They will pay it back over 5 months. Their average income is $12.5 per month per person.

loans.use: Sell noodle

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: There are 6 members of the C. T. family. The grandfather, the father, who is a farmer, and his wife all help out with the wife’s sister’s business. They have two children, who are 12 and 10 years old, who are in the same 7th grade class.  They wish to borrow $75 to invest in a cashew tree that will help to increase and expand their business.  They will pay it back in 5 months time.

loans.use: To plant cashews

loans.name: Hiep

texts.en: Hiep N. T. sells rice soup. Hiep’s husband left her 5 years ago. Hiep’s average income is $11.50 per month/ person. Her oldest daughter works as day labor and helps her mother’s business. Her two younger daughters are in school (6th and 9th grade). She would like to borrow $50 as her capital to get more income to finance her children’s education. She will pay back it in 3 months.

loans.use: To Sell Soup

loans.name: Xi

texts.en: The father works as a day laborer while his wife sells bananas at the small market. Their two children, 7 and 10 years old, are in school (3rd and 5th class). One of them gets our project scholarship. Their average income is $12.50 per month/ person. They want to borrow $75 to raise chickens to get more income so that their children can continue school.  They will pay it back within 4 months.

loans.use: Raise chicken

loans.name: Hanh

texts.en: Hanh N. T. is the mother of 5. Her husband works as a day laborer and she plants rice. Their three children are 6, 9, and 11 years old in school. The family’s average income is $12.50 a month per person, and they would like to apply for a loan of $75 to raise chickens. This would not only provide a source of income for the family, but also provide enough money to continue to educate their children. They will pay back their loan in the next 4 months.

loans.use: Raising chickens

loans.name: Lan

texts.en: Both parents work as day laborers. Their 3 children are 3, 5, and 7 years old. They are in second grade and kindergarten and one gets our project’s scholarship.  The grandfather (80 years old) is blind. Their average income is $10  per month/person. They want to borrow $75 to raise a cow to save to keep their children in school. They will pay it back over 6 months.

loans.use: Raise cow

loans.name: Augustina De La Cruz

texts.en:
Augustina, 22, sells groceries out of a small shed next to her house. She lives with her partner and they have three children. Her partner has a nursery where he sells houseplants. Augustina sells goods like tomatoes, aubergines (eggplant), hot peppers, eggs, vegetable oil, rice, salt and so forth. She started that business very recently.

Now, Augustina needs a loan so as to purchase more goods in order to expand her business and increase her sales volume. This way, Augustina can be sure she´ll improve her family´s situation.

loans.use: To purchase goods like hot pepper, eggplant, rice, and salt in order to increase her income

loans.name: Dong

texts.en: The father is a farmer who plants rice and green dragon but gets low income because of insects and weak investment. The mother has  heartache so she stays home to do housework.  Their 3 oldest children (15, 17 and 19 years old) work as day laborers.  The youngest son (11 years old) is in the 5th grade and gets our project's scholarship.  They want to borrow $75 to invest in their green dragon to get more income to support their family's cost.  They will pay it back over 5 months.

loans.use: Green dragon

loans.name: Saodat

texts.ru:
Saodat’s entire family is engaged in the family’s business. The assortment of goods that Saodat sells includes food products, glass jars and covers, tea, pasta, plastic wrap, etc. During the Winter season, Saodat, with the help of her family, sells and delivers coal. Saodat has been an active MicroInvest client since 2003. Since then, her sales volume increased significantly. Now, Saodat wants to take a loan to purchase plastic wrap, before demand for it begins to grow. Saodat’s husband is on the photo.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Вся семья Саодат занята в бизнесе. Ассортимент ее товаров включает в себя продукты питания, банки и крышки для консервирования, чай, макароны оптом, полиэтиленовую пленку и т.п. Еще она ближе к зимнему периоду привозит и продает уголь. Поэтому чтобы все успеть вся ее семья выходит на базар. В Микроинвест она активный клиент с 2003 г. Обороты ее бизнеса возросли с тех пор в несколько раз. Сейчас она хочет получить новый займ для закупки полиэтиленовой пленки, так как скоро сезон ее продажи. На фото ее муж.

loans.use: For purchase of plastic wrap

loans.name: Anh

texts.en: The family has 4 members. The father works as a day laborer. The mother is a farmer who plants cashew trees. Their two children (14, 17 years old) are in the 8th and 11th class, and their average income is $12 per month/ person. They want to borrow $75 to invest in their cashew garden to provide their children’s school. One of their children is getting our project scholarship. They will pay back this loan in 5 months.

loans.use: Plant cashews

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en: Esmeralda is a 29-year-old single mother.  She has three children that are studying in the public school of the small town.  She prepares and sells fried chicken pieces, fried bananas, and empanadas.  She plans to invest the loan requested to purchase raw materials like flour, spices and so on, to keep producing her fried foods.  She also plans to buy more bananas and chicken than before and thus increase her earnings.  That way, Esmeralda will be better able to cope with her children's needs.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials like bananas, flour, spices and chicken in order to prepare fried foods for sale

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en: The father plants green dragon (120 pileups) and also works as a day laborer. The mother is a tailor. Their average income is $12, $5 per month per person. Their two children (9 and 10 years old) are in the 3rd and 5th class. They want to borrow $75 to invest in their green dragon to get more income to support their family. They will pay it back during 5 months.

loans.use: Green dragon

loans.name: Marcelina Severino

texts.en:
Marcelina, 55 years old, mother of four children, is a very serious and dynamic woman. Her children are living in Santo Domingo, the capital, where they work and have their own families. Marcelina and her husband sell different kinds of seeds. They started doing so twenty years ago. Marcelina will be the ´administrator´ of the business, since her husband is getting old and can´t work as hard as he did before.

Marcelina is requesting a loan to purchase a larger amount of seeds which will be stored in their small storehouse. That way, it will be easier for them to sell their products. The entrepreneur will also be better able to face possible health issues of her husband and improve the couple's well-being.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of seeds to have readily available to resell  to customers

loans.name: Vi

texts.en: The parents have two children (6 and 5 years old) who currently are in school. Their father works as day laborer whiL. his wife takes care their children and works in their green dragon garden. Their average income is $12. 5 per month/ person. They want to borrow $75 to invest their green dragon garden so they can earn more money to save for their children’s education. They will pay back their loan within the next 5 months.

loans.use: Green dragon

loans.name: Duong

texts.en: My parents work as day laborers who plant and farm corn. Their three children, who are 11, 13 and 15 years old, are in the 5th and 6th grade. My family’s average income is $12.50 per month per person. We would like to borrow $75 so we can raise pigs in order to save money for school. We will pay the money back after 5 months.

loans.use: Raise Pigs

loans.name: Farogat

texts.ru:
Farogat is married and has 3 children. She has been selling on a market for a few years. At first, her store was very small and could one a tiny counter. Gradually, Farogat expanded her business, and now she owns a small store. Farogat sells clothing and underwear for women. Since receiving her first loan in 2003, Farogat has been an active client of MicroInvest. She needs this loan to purchase inventory of warm closing for the approaching cold season.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Фарогат уже несколько лет выходит на базар. Вначале ее бизнес был незначительным и размещался на небольшом прилавке. Постепенно она расширила его и сейчас она торгует в небольшом магазинчике. Получив в 2003 году первый займ в Микроинвест она с тех пор является его активной клиенткой. Ассортимент ее товаров включает в себя женскую одежду и нижнее белье. Фарогат замужем и воспитывает 3 детей. На новый займ она планирует закупить теплую женскую одежду так как скоро сезон.

loans.use: To purchase warm clothing for women

loans.name: Monsa

texts.en:
Monsa, 44-year-old mother of three children, is a very hard-working and dynamic person. Three years ago, Monsa opened a bar where only beer was sold. She offers the principal and best Dominican beers like Presidente, Bohemia and also Brahma (made by a Brasilian company that is producing beer in this country).

Currently, Monsa doesn´t have a refrigerator to keep the drinks cold, so she is obliged to purchase many ice packs every day, in order to serve iced beverages to her customers. To remedy that uncomfortable situation, the entrepreneur is requesting a loan to buy a used refrigerator, so that she can handily satisfy her clientele´s needs.

loans.use: To purchase a used refrigerator in order to keep drinks cold and satisfy her customers´ needs

loans.name: Reina Martínez

texts.en:
Reina, 57, is married and is mother of a large family. In fact, the couple has eleven children.

Reina owns a clothing store. She started her business ten years ago. She buys garments in Santo Domingo, the capital, or Dajabón, located on the border with Haiti, where she finds variety and good prices.

The businesswoman is requesting a loan which will be used to purchase a large amount of clothes to be sold during the holiday season. Given this loan, Reina will be able to help her husband deal with their housing issues.

loans.use: To purchase garments to be sold during the holiday season and expand her business

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 32 years old. He is married and has 4 children. One of them has asthma. He has a small car welding shop in Kirkuk. He applied to borrow $1200 to purchase a new welding machine and some spare parts. He also wants to renovate the shop in order to develop his business and increase his income.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase a new welding machine

loans.name: Rahmon

texts.ru:
For many years, Rahmon and his wife have been teaching in a secondary school. Unfortunately, schoolteacher’s pay is not enough to sustain a family. Therefore, a few years ago, Rahmon S.’s family started a business. At first, they sold clothing and shoes for women. Gradually expanding the business, Rahmon also opened a wholesale food store. Rahmon’s younger daughters help their father to sell. Rahmon has been a MicroInvest client for 5 years. MicroInvest loans helped Rahmon considerably expand his business. With this loan Rahmon plans to purchase Fall clothing collection.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Рахмон и его жена работают преподавателями в средней школе. Стаж их работы в школе уже много лет. Заработка преподавателя не хватает на семейные расходы и поэтому семья Солиева Рахмона уже несколько лет занимается бизнесом. Начинали бизнес с продажи женской одежды и обуви. Постепенно расширились и открыли еще одну торговую точку по продаже продуктов питания. Реализация продуктов питания идет оптом. Рахмону помогают и его младшие дочери. С Микроинвест он сотрудничает уже 5-ый год. С помощью займов он значительно расширил свой бизнес. Новый займ собирается потратить на осенний ассортимент одежды.

loans.use: To purchase autumn assortment of clothing

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
Mariana, 38, owns a little cafeteria where she sells fried bananas, boiled or fried eggs, some other fried foods, coffee, milk, and juice in the morning. At midday, she prepares rice with peas, fried chicken, and greens.

Mariana started the cafeteria three years ago. The loan requested is to invest in the purchase of a larger amount of raw materials for the preparation of the food she sells. That way, Mariana will better satisfy her customers´ needs, increase her income, and help her husband improve living conditions for their three sons (12, 10, and 8 years old).

loans.use: To purchase raw materials like bananas, eggs and green vegetables to prepare for her business

loans.name: Thu

texts.en: Thu D. T. would like a loan of $75 to buy another cow. He hopes the two cows will mate so his family can  make more money to continue his 11th grade son’s education. Their average income will increase $3 more per month with the addition of this cow. They will pay back the loan back in 6 months.

loans.use: To raise a cow.

loans.name: Assaad

texts.en: Assaad is a 33-year-old father of three children. He lives with his family in the region of Tyre, where he grows vegetables. He needs $1,200 to fumigate the greenhouses he works in so as to control the emergence of weeds. Assaad needs to generate more revenue in order to take care of his nine-month-old daughter, who suffers from a chest allergy.

loans.use: Fumigation of greenhouses

loans.name: Sicta

texts.en:
Sicta, 48 years old, is married, with eleven children (five boys and six girls). Her husband is a farmer. She sells fresh chicken parts and vegetables like cabbage, and condiments like leeks, cloves, and so forth. Sicta needs a loan to purchase a large amount of those goods in order to easily cope with her customers´ demand. Recently she has been short of those goods, and it´s not good for business to run short of things.

Given this loan, Sicta will be able to continue providing a good education and nourishing food for her children and improve the family´s economic situation.

loans.use: To purchase goods like chicken, vegetables, spices, leeks, and cloves for her business

loans.name: Shohista

texts.ru:
Shohista’s husband is in Russia working as a seasonal laborer. Shohista is 35. She has 2 children. The money that her husband sends over is not enough to sustain her family, so Shohista earns the rest by selling clothing and shoes for children. She received her first MicroInvest loan in 2003. Since then, Shohista increased the assortment and improved the quality of goods sold. She plans to use this loan to refresh her Fall clothing inventory.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Муж Шохисты находится на заработках в России. Ей 35 лет, у нее 2 детей. Присылаемых мужем денег не хватает на жизнь, тем более растут дети и поэтому Шохиста занимается предпринимательством. Она продает детскую одежду и обувь. В Микроинвест первый займ получила в 2003 году. С тех пор в ее бизнесе произошли изменения в лучшую сторону. Увеличен ассортимент и улучшено качество продаваемого товара. С новым займом она собирается обновить осенний ассортимент одежды.

loans.use: To refresh clothing inventory

loans.name: Abbass

texts.en: Abbass lives in the region of Tyre with his family. He is a 51-year-old father of five children. He owns a tire shop and is taking the initiative to develop his business. He needs $700 to expand his business. The revenue generation will help him build an extra room in his small house.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Bertinto Alexandre

texts.pt:
Bertinto lives with his partner and three children (the oldest is already in school). He joined the credit program in 2006. His retail business is doing well, and he has recently started selling clothing articles, in addition to cosmetics and beauty supplies. He plans to use his $300 loan to increase/diversify his inventory. He hopes to be able to build a brick house in the near future, so that he can move his family out of the wattle and daub house they now live in.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Bertinto e solteiro mas vive com uma mulher com quem tem 3 filhos. o mais velho esta a estudar.Bertinto entrou para o programa de credito do Fundo de Desenvolvimento da Mulher em 2006.Ele vende produtos de beleza. Porque o negocio esta a correr bem ele iniciou tambem a venda de roupa.No futuro com os lucros ele pensa construir uma casa usando material convencial, pois a que tem agora e de pau a pique.

loans.use: Bertinto plans on using his loan to buy more cosmetics and beauty supplies for his retail business.

loans.name: Suzana Joao

texts.pt:
Suzana is the mother of two small children. She joined the credit program in 2006. She is doing well selling clothes at the market and plans to use her loan to buy more clothing, so she can offer prospective buyers a larger quantity/variety of pieces. If the business continues to be profitable, she plans to make improvements to her house and to save money for her kids' education.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Suzana e solteira mas tem 2 filhos. Os filhos de Suzana ainda nao estudam. Ela entrou para o programa de credito em 2006. Ela vende roupa no mercado. Ela quer usar o dinheiro para adquirir mais pecas de vestuario para a revenda.Se o negocio continuar a correr bem pensa em melhorar a sua casa, e guardar dinheiro para pagar a escola dos seus filhos quando eles comecarem a estudar.

loans.use: Suzana plans to use her loan to buy more clothing, so she can offer prospective buyers a larger quantity/variety of pieces.

loans.name: Saquina

texts.pt:
Saquina is a widow who works very hard to raise her five children on her own. She joined the credit program in 2006. She started a business selling fish, which she buys from local fishermen, and because things were going well she begun selling staples, as well. Saquina will use her loan to buy more fish and increase her staples inventory. Profits from the business will help her improve her children's diet and save for their education.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Saquina e vivuva. Tem 5 filhod. Alguns filhos de saquina estudam outros nao por serem ainda menores. Ela entrou para o programa de credito em 2006.Ela vende peixe, mas porque o negocio esta a correr bem introduziu tambem a venda de produtos de primeira necessidade.Ela quer usar o dinheiro para reforcar o negocio dela. Com os lucros pretende investir na educacao dos filhos e melhorar a dieta alimentar deles.Ela precisa de trabalhar muito para criar os filhos.

loans.use: Saquina will use her loan to buy more fresh fish and staples to sell at her market.

loans.name: Avelino Fabiao

texts.pt:
Avelino lives with his partner and two young children. He joined the credit program in 2006. Previous loans have helped him improve his business of selling clothes and household appliances. He will use his loan to increase his inventory and, if the business continues to be profitable, plans to build a brick house and save for the education of his children.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Avelino e solteiro mas vive com uma mulher com quem tem 2 filhos ainda pequenos. Entrou para o Programa em 2006. Ele quer usar o dinheiro para a compra de mais electrodomesticos e mais roupa para a venda.O negoci esta a corre-lhe bem. Ele pensa com os lucros construir uma casa de alvenarias para a sua familia. e guardar dinheiro para a educacao dos seus filhos.

loans.use: Avelino will use his loan to buy more clothing and household appliances for his retail business.

loans.name: Olivio Paulo

texts.pt:
Olivio lives with his partner and three young children. He joined the credit program in 2007, and is now on his second cycle. When Olivio's plans of pursuing a college education didn't work out he decided to start a business selling vegetal coal, to support his family. If his business continues to do well he plans on building a home of his own, so him and his family can move out of his parents' house, where they currently live.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Olivio e solteiro mas vive com uma mulher com quem tem 3 filhos.Entrou para o programa em 2007 e esta no segundo ciclo.Os filhos de Olivio ainda nao vao a escola, porqie ainda nao tem idade suficiente para ingressarem na escola.m mas assim que atingirem a idade recomendada eles serao matriculados. Olivia tinha plano de continuar a estudar no ensino superior mas nao conseguiu transitar para a Universidade. Assim ele optou por fazer o negoci da venda de carvao para sustentar a sua familia. Se tudo correr bem, pensa construir a sua propria residencia, pois que agora vive com os pais.

loans.use: Olivio will use his loan for the buying and transportation of more vegetal coal

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Koné Man lives in Treichville, a township in the south of Abidjan. Koné Man is 26 years old and is one of 3 children.  She sells dry peppers and various aromatic products in the Treichville market. Koné Man wants to diversify her product range by selling food products from neighboring country Mali in addition to her current products. In addition she will also use part of the loan to help pay for her younger brothers eductation in secondary school. She joined our micro credit program 2 years ago and has always been a good performer.

loans.use: Man Koné will use the loan to purchase goods and pay school expenses

loans.name: Alberto

texts.en:
Alberto makes artisan crafts and works with straw manufacturing baskets, hats, place mats, etc. He also sells cow milk, from which he supplements his earnings in order to support his wife and three children. He lives in Comunidad de Batallas – Caluyo (two hours away from La Paz). He will use the loan for buying a milking cow of medium breed in order to increase milk production. This is his second credit through Impro and his good payment records qualify him for obtaining another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Alberto es artesano y realiza trabajo manual en paja como ser cestería, sombreros e individuales de comedor, etc. También es productor de leche de vaca con cuyas ventas complementa sus ingresos y así mantiene a sus tres hijos y esposa. Vive en la Comunidad de Batallas - Caluyo (A dos horas y media de la ciudad de La Paz). El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una vaca de raza mediana para incrementar la producción de leche. Es el segundo crédito con Impro y el buen historial de pagos le permite acceder a otro préstamo.

loans.use: Buying a milking cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Fabio

texts.en:
Fabio and his wife are milk producers and small-sized farmers selling vegetables in the city of La Paz. These activities are their main source of income in order to support their family. He lives in Comunidad Palomar Rio – Palomar (2 hours south of the city of La Paz). He will use the loan for buying a milking cow of medium breed in order to increase milk production. This is his first credit through Impro and his financial evaluation shows a good cash flow that qualifies him for obtaining a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Fabio y su esposa son productores de leche de vaca y pequeños agricultores de hortalizas que comercializan en la ciudad de La Paz; estas actividades son su principal fuente de ingreso con la que cubre la manutención de su familia. Vive en la Comunidad de Palomar Rio – Palomar , al Sur de La Ciudad de La Paz (A dos horas de la ciudad de La Paz). El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una vaca de raza mediana para incrementar la producción de leche. Es el primer crédito con Impro y la evaluación realizada muestra un buen flujo de caja y lo califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Buying a milking cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo is a milk producer and works as a public transportation driver in the city of La Paz. This is how he supplements his income in order to support his wife and four children. He lives in Comunidad Palomar Rio – Palomar (2 hours south of the city of La Paz). He will use the loan for buying a milking cow of medium breed in order to increase milk production and supply the demand in the area. This is his first credit through Impro and his socioeconomic evaluation qualifies him for granting a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Eduardo es productor de leche de vaca y trabaja de transportista publico en la ciudad de La Paz; de esta forma complementa sus ingresos con los que cubre la manutención de sus 4 hijos y esposa. Vive en la Comunidad de Palomar Rio – Palomar, al Sur de La Ciudad de La Paz (A dos horas de la ciudad de La Paz). El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una vaca de raza mediana para incrementar la producción de leche y satisfacer la demanda en la zona. Es el primer crédito con Impro y la evaluación socio-económica realizada lo califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Buying a milking cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Rokia

texts.en: Rokia Koné has lived with her mother for all her life, until she passed away a few months ago. Rokia now lives with her fiancé in Treichville in the south of Abidjan. She has been selling vegetables in the market there for 15 years. Her fiancé helps her financially and Rokia wants to expand and develop her business in order to become more independent. She will use the loan to purchase goods in bulk so she can resell them to school and restaurant during the upcoming year. Ms. Koné will pay off the loan over a 15 month period.

loans.use: Koné Rokia will use the loan to purchase goods in bulk

loans.name: Lilian

texts.es:
Lilian is a flower vendor in the cemetaries of La Paz. She also manufactures cow's milk and thus supplements her income for one that can keep her. Lilian lives in her parent's home in the community of Rio Abajo - Palomar (two hours outside of the city of La Paz). The loan will be used to purchase a medium range cow to increase her production of milk and try to improve her income. This is her first loan with Impro and her evaluation allowed her to be approved for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Eric Strader, Kiva Volunteer

Lilian es comerciante de flores en los cementerios de La Paz; también es productora de leche de vaca y así complementa sus ingresos con los que se mantiene. Lilian vive en la casa de sus padres en la Comunidad de Rio Abajo – Palomar (a dos horas de la ciudad de La Paz). El crédito será utilizado para comprar una vaca de raza mediana para incrementar su producción de leche y tratar de mejorar sus ingresos. Es el primer crédito con Impro y la evaluación realizada permite aprobarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Compra de vaca lechera

loans.name: Guillermo

texts.es:
Guillermo is a milk producer and has a small vegetable farm. He sells both products in the city of La Paz., Bolivia. Sales from these two activities constitutes his income with which he supports his 4 children and wife. He lives in the town of Palomar Rio. Palomar is two hours south of La Paz.

The loan will be used to buy a dairy cow of an ordinary breed, so he can increase milk production and improve his income. This is Guillermo's first loan with IMPRO, but he has been approved for a loan in the credit evaluation process.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Guillermo es productor de leche de vaca y pequeño agricultor de hortalizas, las mismas que son comercializadas en la ciudad de La Paz. Los ingresos provenientes de estas dos actividades constituyen su principal ingreso con lo que cubre la manutención de sus 4 hijos y esposa. Vive en la Comunidad de Palomar Rio – Palomar, al Sur de La Ciudad de La Paz (A dos horas de la ciudad de La Paz).

El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una vaca de raza mediana para incrementar la producción de leche y así mejorar sus ingresos. Es el primer crédito con Impro y la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Nicolay

texts.es:
Nicolay is a young man of 20 years. He lives with his mother and his little sister. Nicolay was forced to work tailoring clothes and selling bed sets. Nicolay is in his last year of college and he lives in Villa 16 de julio from the city of El Alto.

The loan he requested will be used to buy raw material to support his small shop. He wishes to improve his income to help his family.

This is his first credit with Impro and the social and financial evaluation that was done both qualified him for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Yvette Diaz, Kiva volunteer.

Nicolay, joven de 20 años de edad, vive con su madre y hermana menor; para ayudar a la madre con la manutención de la familia se vio obligado a trabajar como costurero y comerciante de edredones y cubrecamas. Nicolay está en último año de colegio y vive en la zona Villa 16 de julio de la Ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinara para comprar materia prima (compra de tela), de esa forma fortalecerá tu pequeño taller y espera mejorar sus ingresos y por ende, ayudar a la familia.

Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada, tanto social como económica califica a Nicolay para la aprobación del préstamo.

loans.use: Work Capital

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Man Binaté was born in 1969 in Senegal.  She moved to Côte d’Ivoire.  She has been living there for 25 years now and has a fiancé.  They plan to get married very soon.  Her fiancé is Mr Akim Achilou.  They have one child.  Binaté sells spices, palm oil, and many other products in the Treichville market in southern Abidjan.  She has been working for many years.  She needs a loan to open a restaurant.  She is looking to appeal to tradesmen and merchants who are unable to go home at noon for lunch. This generates a lot of business.  She will pay back the loan of $1050 in 15 months.

loans.use: Man Binaté will use the loan to purchase fruits and legumes

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
Juan Carlos and his wife live in their own home in the 18th street of the Llojeta region in the city of La Paz, Bolivia. He sells charcoal and travels twice a week to Yungas and its outskirts where he does business with charcoal factories. He picks up large sacks of charcoal and returns to La Paz to distribute these to vendors. He also packages smaller sacks with aluminum and labels them "Barbeque Charcoal" and sells them in supermarkets throughout La Paz.

The loan he seeks will be used to buy large quantities of charcoal, since there is a very high demand for it in La Paz. Juan Carlos wants to take advantage of this opportunity to establish himself in this market. Although this is his first time with IMPRO, the nature of his business and analysis of his cash flow qualify him for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Juan Carlos vive en casa propia con su esposa e hijos en la calle 18 de la zona de Llojeta de la ciudad de La Paz; la actividad que realiza es la venta de carbón, viaja dos veces por semana a los Yungas y sus alrededores donde tiene contratos con productores de carbon, el cual recoge en sacos grandes y al llegar a La Paz los distribuye a los comerciantes, pero también embolsa el carbon en sacos pequeños de papel aluminio viñeteados con la frase “carbón para parrillada” y los vende a los supermercados de la ciudad de La Paz. Para aclaración, la palabra parrillada es sinónimo de barbecue en inglés.

El crédito solicitado será invertido en la compra de mayor cantidad de carbón, en vista de que la demanda por este producto aun está insatisfecha en la ciudad de La Paz y Juan Carlos desea aprovechar esta oportunidad para consolidar su posición en este mercado. No tiene antecedente con IMPRO pero por la característica de su negocio y el análisis de flujo de caja puede acceder a un crédito.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Kolo

texts.en: Touré Kolo is a dynamic and ambitious tradesman. Touré is single and 32 years old. He lives in Cocody in Abidjan and has his food store in Treichville, in the south of the Abidjan region. Touré wholesale sells potatoes and crops, He joined the AE&I microfinance program early in 2005. He has benefited various loans that he has reimbursed in a timely manner. He has rapidly diversified his product range. Touré wants to replenish his store with onions and dry peppers imported from neighboring country Niger. His products are sold in vast quantities at the end of year because of parties and feasts. Touré is a people person and a entrepreneurial business oriented man.

loans.use: Touré Kolo will purchase batches of onions and peppers from neighboring country Niger

loans.name: Meljabeth Faustina

texts.es:
Mejalbeth is a strong willed woman who despite the dificulties she faced as a child decided to move forward. She started working diligently as a housekeeper and providing support in a district attorneys office.

With her husband´s help four years ago she opened a workshop especialized in creating and selling furniture. The workshop has helped feed and raise her three small children. She has high hopes and dreams for her family and one of her dreams is the expansion of her small workshop to be able to meet the daily requests she gets for the creation of beatiful furniture.

To turn this wish into a reality Mejalbeth requests a loan of $ 275, which will be used to purchase new tools, raw materials, and to refurbish her workshop. She is firmly committed to returning her loan from day one within the loan period. With your loan Mejalbeth and her family will see their lives improved and she will not miss the opportunity to continue providing her clients with beautiful handcrafted furniture.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.

Mejalbeth es una mujer luchadora que a pesar de las dificultades que afrontó cuando aún era muy joven no se amilanó y decidió emprender su vida laboral realizando diversas actividades; trabajó denodadamente de empleada doméstica y también prestó apoyo en la oficina de un fiscal de su querida ciudad en algunas temporadas. Con la ayuda de su esposo hace cuatro años decidió abrir un taller de fabricación de muebles para poder otorgarles sustento y bienestar a sus tres pequeños hijos. Dentro de su hogar existen grandes sueños y anhelos y uno de ellos es el de implementar aún más su pequeño taller para cubrir los pedidos que reciben a diario para la fabricación de bellísimos muebles. Para cristalizar este deseo solicita un préstamo de 275 dólares, con el podrá adquirir más insumos y adicionará a su pequeño centro laboral herramientas para trabajos especializados y/o acabados, desde ya ella se compromete a devolverlos responsablemente en el período pactado.Con tu aporte Mejalbeth y su familia incrementarán su nivel de vida y no perderán la oportunidad de seguir otorgándole finos muebles a sus clientes.

loans.use: Tool purchase and workshop refurbishment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying more merchandise.

loans.name: Laura Luz

texts.es:
Laura is the mother of four children, of which two are outside of the home because they have created their own families. The other two are studying in the city university. She lives with her husband, who works in transit as a taxi driver and is also in charge of filling Laura's purchase orders for the small warehouse they have installed in their home. Before Laura came to this work she made traditional food for her neighbors on her patio and during the morning offered first aid articles in the same place. With the passing days Laura realized that she was well received and decided to invest in the start up of a small warehouse. The fruit of her patience and perseverance was the construction of a small kiosk. Now dedicating herself completely to this activity with the help of her dear daughters, who alternate with helping their loving mother at work. Actually, she cannot count on the assorted stock of items in her small warehouse to satisfy the demand of her clients and neighbors. To do this she is asking for a loan in the sum of $350, an amount which she promises to repay in 6 months. Let us be sure that this self-sacrificing mother can continue oversee the wellbeing of her family through this enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Eric Strader, Kiva Volunteer

Laura es madre de cuatro hijas, de las cuales dos están fuera del hogar porque han constituido sus respectivas familias y las otras dos están cursando estudios superiores en la universidad de su ciudad, vive con su esposo que se dedica al servicio de transporte público en su mototaxi y también se encarga de realizar las respectivas compras por encargo de su esposa para la pequeña bodega que han instalado en su domicilio. Laura antes de desempeñarse en esta labor ofrecía platos típicos a sus vecinos en el patio de su casa y durante la mañana hacía lo mismo con los artículos de primera necesidad en este mismo lugar.Con el transcurrir de los días se dió cuenta que empezó a tener acogida y decidió invertir en la implementación de su pequeña bodega de ventas, fruto de su paciencia y perseverancia logró construir un pequeño kiosco, dedicándose ahora por completo a esta actividad con el apoyo de sus queridas hijas que se alternan para aliviar el trabajo de su querida madre. Actualmente no cuenta con un surtido stock de artículos en su bodega para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes y vecinos y para realizar esta implementación necesita la suma de 350 dólares, monto que se compromete a devolverlos en seis meses. Hagamos que esta abnegada madre siga brindando bienestar a su familia a través de su digna ocupación.

loans.use: Purchase of warehouse stock to increase her sales.

loans.name: Nora Idalia

texts.es:
Nora is a married woman and her husband works as a chauffer. They have a child. The main motivation to start her business was the need for income to help her husband with the household expenses. Since her husband's job is variable and undependable that made things worse, so she started first selling shoes through catalogues until she had formed a clientele and little by little grew and set up shelves in her house to display the merchandise she was promoting. Now she is also very enthusiastically selling cosmetics, so she can increase her market and sales for both products.

Nora is requesting a loan for US$925 to cover pending orders and buy more merchandise to offer her clients. She offers to pay back the loan in 6 months. She is thankful for your support in helping her get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga and son, Kiva volunteers.

Nora es una mujer casada y su esposo trabaja como chofer, tienen un hijo y el principal motivo para emprender su negocio fue la necesidad de ingresos para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y como el empleo de su esposo es eventual eso empeoraba su situación, entonces ella empezó vendiendo primero zapatos por catálogo hasta crear una cartera de clientes y poco a poco con su crecimiento puso un estante en su casa para colocar y mostrar las promociones que tenía y ahora vende cosméticos, en los que esta poniéndole muchas ganas para poder incrementar su mercado y tener las ventas de sus dos productos.

Nora esta solicitando un préstamo por la cantidad de US $ 925 para cubrir pedidos pendientes, surtirse de más productos para ofrecer a sus clientes, ofreciendo pagar el préstamo en 6 meses. Ella te agradece mucho tu apoyo para ayudarla a salir adelante.

loans.use: Buying merchanidise for her business

loans.name: Nelly Margarita

texts.es:
Nelly is married and has 2 children. Her husband works as an employee and his salary is not enough to cover the household expenses. This is why Nelly decided to help her husband with expenses by setting up her business selling cosmetics, starting by doing demonstrations of her products in markets and in her home. Then she demonstrated her products door to door, and little by little she has increased her clientele, many of whom are now regular clients, so she has several orders secured every month. She wants to continue with her business.

Nelly is requesting a loan for US $925 to cover pending orders and buy merchandise to continue her demonstrations and obtain greater income for her family. She offers to pay the loan in 6 months. She is thankful for the support you give her to continue her business.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga and son, Kiva volunteers.
